Email_Body: WITH Bo Jackson sidelined, marketing experts have been wondering who will replace him as the best pitchman in advertising. Some believe the next superstar endorser is David Robinson. David knows basketball.Mr. Robinson, the 7-foot 1-inch center for the San Antonio Spurs, is already the stuff of legend, a rare professional athlete whose basketball scores (25.6 points a game on average) were rivaled, relatively speaking, by his Scholastic Aptitude Test scores (1,320 out of 1,600). A mathematics major at the United States Naval Academy, Mr. Robinson served a two-year hitch with the Navy, remains a lieutenant and civil engineer in the Reserves, won a bronze medal as a member of the 1988 United States Olympic basketball team, is a concert pianist and in 1990 was voted the National Basketball Association's rookie of the year.Marketers are always searching for the next great endorser, in hopes that the celebrity's aura will lend a magic glow to their product or service. There are those who say Mr. Robinson's future is limitless."I think without a doubt David Robinson has superstar qualities," said Nova Lanktree, the director of Burns Sports Celebrity Service, a Chicago firm that matches athletes with advertising agencies. "Very often, when an agency calls us, they'll not know who they want, and we'll always recommend Robinson and they'll say, 'Oh, yeah!' And if the agency has already been reviewing basketball stars, Robinson's name is always on the list."While he was still in the Navy, Mr. Robinson signed endorsement contracts with Casio watches and Franklin Sports Industries. He also signed withNikeInc., the athletic shoe company that made "Bo knows" part of the American vernacular.Nikelured Mr. Robinson into a five-year, $1 million endorsement deal in 1988, before he joined the Spurs. A year ago, the company inaugurated a $15 million advertising campaign for its Force basketball shoe line, with the giant center as the star of "Mr. Robinson's Neighborhood," a parody of the children's show "Mister Rogers's Neighborhood.""Not only is David Robinson what some people consider the future of basketball -- a big man who's incredibly fast -- but he's also an exceptionally wonderful human being," said Jim Riswold, an associate creative director at Wieden & Kennedy, the Portland, Ore., advertising agency that handlesNike."When I walked out of my first meeting with him a couple of years ago, it was his niceness that impressed me," Mr. Riswold said. "Michael Prieve, an agency art director, agreed and suggested that there was nobody nicer than children's show hosts. We built from there, and that's what you see."In each of the dozen or so spots Wieden & Kennedy has filmed, Mr. Robinson invites the audience, and sometimes a guest star, into his realm -- the basketball court -- to learn a new word or phrase. When Charles Barkley, the obstreperous forward of the Philadelphia 76er's, was the guest, Mr. Robinson asked, "Can you say, 'Fined?' "The commercials have not been without controversy. Last year, after viewer complaints,Nikecanceled an ad that ran during the World Series in which Mr. Robinson asked, "Can you say, 'Kick some butt?' "Jeff Austin, a vice president of Advantage International and Mr. Robinson's agent, said the Spurs' center recently signed two other large endorsement contracts, but declined to identify the companies involved.Ms. Lanktree, the sports marketing executive, said Mr. Robinson's allure was based partly on intangible factors. "You're talking about a young man, a concert pianist, 1,300 S.A.T. scores, and he still thanks his coaches for teaching him," she said.But Ms. Lanktree also noted that Mr. Robinson was benefiting from canny marketing by the N.B.A. itself, which has moved to broaden pro basketball's somewhat elitist image."Ten years ago, the N.B.A. was a spectator sport that rich people went to see," Ms. Lanktree said. "Now the general public is getting to know it and its stars, like Michael Jordan and Magic Johnson, and they're giving the game more mass appeal. David Robinson is in on the ground floor of its growth."For all that, there are still those who say it will be hard for Mr. Robinson to achieve Bo Jackson's level as an endorser. Mr. Jackson reportedly earned about $2 million a year fromNikeand $3 million from A.T.&T., Pepsico and other companies.Martin E. Blackman, whose New York firm, Blackman & Raber, is a top matchmaker between athletes and advertisers, said Mr. Robinson would suffer from his prowess in just one sport and his team's location in the Southwest. He will not receive "year-round ink," as Mr. Jackson, a two-sport man, did; nor will he receive heavy coverage in a media center, as Mr. Jackson, who played football for the Los Angeles Raiders, did."When you talk in terms of advertising in this country, you're talking about New York and Chicago, where the big agencies are," Mr. Blackman said. "L.A. also gets exposure. Michael Jordan playing basketball for the Chicago Bulls; it doesn't hurt that McDonald's ad agency, Leo Burnett, is there. And Michael Jordan is doing a big thing for McDonald's.""I believe David Robinson will become a leading product spokesperson, because he's got what it takes," Mr. Blackman concluded. "But I don't see him yet in the sphere of Michael Jordan or Bo Jackson."Mr. Robinson's agent, Mr. Austin, is not worried. "David does not necessarily want his name on 50 products," he said. "That approach is appropriate for Mary Lou Retton, whose celebrity is more of-the-moment. David is going to have longevity."

Email_Body: Chiat/Day/Mojo in New York has regained a large part of the Reebok International account after the sport-shoe company abruptly pulled its $US40 million account from Hill, Holiday, Connors, Cosmopulos last Friday.The business will be split between Chiat/Day/Mojo and Lois/GGK.Reebok would not comment on its reasons for dismissing Hill, Holiday, a move that comes a little less than a year after the Boston agency won the account in a highly publicised review. But agency executives said Reebok had made the move because Hill, Holiday's ads failed to create excitement for the company's athletic shoes or to gain ground onNike, which is number one.Executives at Hill, Holiday would not comment. The agency had produced only one big campaign for Reebok. With the tag-line "It's time to play", the ads showed athletes and others playing in their Reeboks.Some agency executives said Reebok had become desperate to find a hardhitting campaign to use against the comparative ads from some of its competitors, and it turned to Lois/GGK late last year to produce commercials for its "pump" shoes.The campaign from Lois/GGK, called "Pump up and Air out", featured athletes taking a swipe atNike'sspokesman, Michael Jordan of the Chicago Bulls of the National Basketball Association, and the maker's Air Jordan shoes.The campaign was criticised by its competitors and some agency executives because it took what they said was an unwarranted pot-shot at Jordan.Ms Bernadette Mansur, a spokeswoman for Reebok, said the company was pleased with the ads from Lois/GGK. "They created a buzz about Reebok with retailers and consumers," she said.Although Chiat/Day had resigned the bulk of the Reebok account in January 1990 after it was put in review, the agency has continued to create advertising for the company's Weeboks children's shoes and for its business outside the United States.Agency executives said Reebok was a difficult client. The said the company demanded innovative approaches but then often criticised an agency for "being too creative".Chiat/Day, which had the entire Reebok account for three years before the bulk of it went to Hill, Holiday, lost the account in large part because of its quirky "Reebok lets UBU" campaign, which Reebok executives reportedly thought was too far out.The commercials showed people doing idiosyncratic things such as vacuuming a carpet on a lawn.The ads were criticised within the advertising industry for not focusing on the performance of the athletic shoes and for not increasing sales.While Chiat/Day had the account, Reebok lost its number one position toNike.Chiat/Day handles the pan-European Reebok business out of its London office, and South-East Asian business from Singapore.Now that Reebok is back, Mr Jay Chiat, the chairman and chief executive world-wide of Chiat/Day/Mojo, said he was pleased. "It's great," he said. "Clients don't often return to an agency."Reebok is the latest in a number of clients who have split their accounts between agencies to double their chances of getting good work.In the past few years both Burger King and IBM have divided their businessAlthough this set-up could obviously foster competitive rivalries, Mr George Lois, the chairman and chief executive of Lois/GGK, said he was not worried."There is no reason we can't be a great team," he said.

Email_Body: It's official. Well almost. Half the tennis world thinks Andre Agassi is an irrepressible, lovable brat; the other half finds him an insufferable little prat. Or, in the local south London vernacular, a plonker.In a recent national TV poll in the US, he topped the polls for both the most popular and least popular person playing tennis today. That should surprise no-one: Andre is, by his own admission, a kinda crazy, mixed-up guy, drooled over by teenyboppers, damned by the traditionalists.Love him or loathe him, as they always seem to be saying of Andre, many people were counting on being able to ignore him and his hype this week at Wimbledon. Alas, it has not been possible.The brat is back-four years, almost to the day, since being sent from SW19 after a humiliating straight-sets defeat by Henri Leconte. Between times, Agassi has won 12 tour titles (although, significantly, no grand slam yet), established himself as one of the world's top players on clay, and risen to fifth overall, with prize money to date of more than $A6 million.While doing so, he has repeatedly declined to play Wimbledon, saying he needed a rest and, anyway, his style of play was not suited to the faster grass courts.Now, aged 21, he returns, not much more mature, but a considerably improved player and infinitely more marketable.Just askNike, whose clothing he wears (sometimes he seems to wear them all at once, in clashing Technicolor) as part of a deal worth more than $A5 million a year. Marketing boss Ian Hamilton says Agassi is the company's biggest asset these days,Nike'sJohn McEnroe notwithstanding.Or, just ask the kids selling postcards from a kiosk in front of the All England Club; they confirm that Agassi portraits have been outselling pix of all the girls put together this week.Never mind that the buyers tend to be female and under 14, Agassi has become a megastar, albeit one whose court performances are still trying to catch up with his razzle-dazzle showbiz persona.Of course, just as the Fawlty Towers waiter Manuel was explained away as being "from Barcelona", so Andre Agassi is "from Las Vegas". As The Times remarked rather sniffily, this is not a good introduction to the real world.Not that Agassi spends much time there. As he says in a typically brash, brainless TV commercial for camera company Canon, "Image is everything".So, all this week, in a series of newspaper articles, he has sought to shock with "revelations" of his teenage rebelliousness. They seem pretty innocuous, in fact. Like many All American boys, Agassi did a little pot, drank a lot of Jack Daniels and, in an attempt to upset his teachers, grew his hair long.Nowadays, he insists, the length of every flowing, multi-coloured hair on that treasured head is stipulated in his sponsorship contracts. And the mainstays in his life are not drink and drugs but God, two Porsches, a Ferrari and a Lamborghini, and a cockatoo named Fred (although not necessarily in that order, one suspects).Whether Agassi really believes his own publicity is doubtful. While publicly he wants to be a hard-assed rad dude, privately he is more Ninja Turtle: not exactly self-effacing but less vulgar, more vulnerable.Certainly, the man-child who enjoyed the recent French Open so much he pronounced himself "as happy as a faggot in a submarine" has come to Wimbledon anxious not to upset the strawberry cart.Critics recall with horror how a year ago he clashed with the International Tennis Federation over the dress code, calling its chief, Phillipe Chatrier, a bozo.It now transpires that months ago he andNikeboss Hamilton reassured the All England Club that Agassi, if he played at Wimbledon, would not turn up looking like a mad dog's dinner. Of possible clashes with the Establishment over his clothes, he demurely explained: "I have no trouble with the traditions of Wimbledon. They will not inconvenience me."Inevitably, the crowd that waited almost four days to see his first-round, rain-delayed match against Canada's Grant Connell were interested less in how he would play, more in what he would wear.Just before 4pm on day four he swept on to centre court, whiter than white. So deferential was his demeanour he even bowed to the royal box. The rest was hysteria: Wimbledon welcomed Agassi.Today, at least, it had decided he was the most popular man in tennis.Even in the short time he was on court before further showers had him running for cover, he demonstrated that somewhere inside the floppy shirt, denim shorts and Lycra pants (be they white or kaleidoscopically wacky) is an exciting and extravagantly skilled player. He's no net rusher, that's for sure, but his powerful ground shots, hit with wicked top spin, are complemented by pace and inventiveness about the court.Given his inexperience on grass, he was expected to struggle early against the left-handed Connell, ranked 73rd in the world, but who this month had beaten Ivan Lendl.So it proved. Though having promised further sartorial surprises in subsequent appearances, Agassi had every incentive to progress to later rounds.

Email_Body: LEN McKENDRY has sprung one of the surprises of the season by recommending temperamental Heidelberg winger Angie Goutzioulis to national coach Eddie Thomson.Goutzioulis has earned three weeks of suspension from bookings and landed an extra week after being sent off early in the game against Wollongong City.But McKendry retained his belief in the player's ability and was justly rewarded when he turned on a match winning performance against Marconi on Sunday. McKendry said Goutzioulis tore apart Marconi full-back Robert Wheatley and was instrumental in Heidelberg's upset 1-0 win."I prefer to describe Angie as highly-spirited rather than difficult to handle, and there is no doubting he is a tremendous prospect," McKendry said."He's got a bad name unnecessarily and I'm trying to convince Eddie Thomson to have a closer look at him."Certainly for us on Sunday, he was given a defensive job as well as going forward, and he did marvellously for us in both areas." Goutzioulis admitted yesterday that the coach had a quiet word after his sending off."Aggression is part of my game but I'm not temperamental," he said."I would like to think I have matured with the bad experience and believe I can play with contained aggression from now on." Goutzioulis' performance earns him the player-of-the-week title in the Herald-SunNikeAir Golden Boot award.The weekly winner receives a pair ofNikeAir runners valued at $280.The end of season winner collects $2000 cash fromNike.Rather than talk about his performance, Goutzioulis prefers to concentrate on the improving form of Heidelberg and has confidently predicted the side can collect another big scalp - that of Melbourne Croatia - this Sunday."It's the first time in 20 weeks that we are at full strength and I really fancy our chances," he said.Goutzioulis broke into the NSL as a central striker, but says he is enjoying his role as a wide player more."I've got a bit of defensive work to do, but playing wide allows to run at players and that suits my game a lot more." ERNIE TAPAI, recovering from a knee operation, has given himself an outside chance of returning to on-field action providing Adelaide City makes the championship play-offs. Tapai, who has been concentrating on swimming in his rehabilitiation program, has resumed light running with the club.IT'S A few months too late, but Heidelberg will finally acknowledge its players' achievement for winning the 1990 State League championship by holding a celebration dinner for team members at the Lexicon restaurant on Sunday night.Herald-SunNikeAir Golden Boot Award.Round 20. Email_Body: ALAN DAVIDSON'S return to international soccer may well be in jeopardy with his decision to postpone indefinitely the operation he needs to repair knee ligaments.Davidson was told by Socceroo doctor Siri Kanangara to book in for the operation, but the utility has delayed it for several weeks to help out Melbourne Croatia. He has now decided to postpone surgery until the end of the season. "I've put it on hold and will get it done when I can (after the season)," he said yesterday. "We have had a lot of injuries and suspensions and I agreed to delay it."The club knows I could break down any time or, providing I'm lucky, I could go right through."Davidson's operation will rule him out for up to five weeks and, if he was to have it immediately after the league campaign, it would virtually rule him out of international commitments.He may delay it further but at this stage he doesn't want to think that far ahead. The media hailed Davidson's performance on the weekend as his best club game for several seasons.His display in Melbourne Croatia's match at Olympic earns him the player-of-the-week title in the Herald-SunNikeAir Golden Boot award.The weekly winner receives a pair ofNikeAir runners valued at $280.The end of season winner, based on the weekly votes, collects $2000 cash.St George keeper John Filan remains the leader on 18 votes. Davidson has moved up to 12 votes.Herald-SunNikeAir Golden Boot Award. Round 23. Votes: Adelaide v Heidelberg: 3 Veart (ac), 2 Brattan (h), 1 Herd (h). Email_Body: Staid Wimbledon set for fashion sensation London FORGET the tennis one of the most constantly asked questions as the countdown to Wimbledon hits top gear is: "Just what will Andre Agassi be wearing?" Not since Gussie Moran outraged the establishment with her lace pants in 1949 has fashion been so prominent in pre-Wimbledon discussions.While Agassi licks his wounds over losing last week's French Open final to fellow American Jim Courier, it seems almost everyone else is licking their lips in anticipation of what the luminous lad from Las Vegas will turn out in when he makes his much-anticipated Wimbledon return in 11 days. During this year's Parisian sojourn Agassi followed up his lava pink outfit of 1990 by bustling around the red clay courts of Roland Garros in a black, purple and white combination.That ensemble is certainly out of the question for the staid lawns of Wimbledon, where anything but predominantly white is no-go. So just what will Agassi, or rather his sponsors,Nike, come up with for the All England Championships, which start on Monday week? The man himself is not saying."You've waited for three years to see, so I guess you can wait another few days," Agassi said when asked in Paris.The world No 5 is revelling in the tease surrounding his choice of garb. He andNikeknow a good marketing ploy when they see one.Agassi is also reported to be exclusively contracted to reveal all to a London tabloid newspaper.Despite the secrecy rumours abound.The word, according to one media hound, is that the Las Vegas showman will turn out for his first match in classical white from his headband down to his cycling shorts.After that, he said, Agassi was likely to introduce a lightly coloured outfit.Reports this week saidNike, after discussing designs with Agassi, had been putting alternatives to the All England Committee and referee Alan Mills for approval.At the centre of the commotion is rule 8 of Wimbledon's "Conditions of Entry and Participation" which states that except for the warm-up period, all competitors must be dressed "predominantly in white" during matches.To contravene the rule leaves a player liable for default.John McEnroe is among its more famous victims, when he was required to change his dark blue shorts on centre court.The Times newspaper said no one could quite remember when the rule was cast in iron, but Wimbledon is the only one of the four Grand Slam tournaments to have such a strict dress code.Last year Agassi's hot pink outfit caused Philippe Chatrier, head of both the French Tennis Federation and International Tennis Federation, to suggest the introduction of a "predominantly white" rule for the French Open.It led to a war of words with Agassi during the 1990 titles, but the issue did not arise this month when Agassi turned out in Paris in his toned-down, yet still colourful, combination.The "predominantly white" tradition is not greeted with enthusiasm by the multi-million dollar leisurewear industry.Last year Italian clothing outfit Diadora, which had guaranteed Jennifer Capriati $4.65 million for a five-year contract, had its range for the American whiz-kid turned down just before her Wimbledon debut.The teenager, at the age of 14, was the youngest player to appear at Wimbledon and was the media sensation of the year."You want to be able to make stuff you can sell," said Ian Hamilton ofNike."One of the problems is that 'predominantly white' does not sell and we can't keep producing clothes we cannot sell in shops." Alfred Schwarz, head of sports promotions for Adidas, which has Stefan Edberg and Steffi Graf as clients, told The Times : "The ruling makes us nervous because we have to guess when we produce our ranges what will be acceptable to Wimbledon, but it is very difficult to get all the manufacturers together to lobby for a more precise definition."From an image point of view, Wimbledon is the most watched event of any through the year."It has a certain meaning, but the design rule is a problem, and we feel that is our domain, not Wimbledon's." For Wimbledon, however, a priority is to protect the championships' tradition.Chris Gorringe, chief executive of the All England Club, admitted the rule was ill-defined but said officials did not think it right to stipulate any percentage of white."A very small amount of psychedelic colouring can be off-putting, while a pastel-coloured shirt could be perfectly acceptable," he said."We feel and I think the players feel too that this is one of our better traditions." Agassi, whose talent is undoubted, will be making his first appearance at Wimbledon since 1987, when he was beaten in the first round.His ability to hone his hard court game to the vagaries of grass is not the only thing everyone is waiting to see.

Email_Body: Foot in mouth disease NOW it can be told _ the true story of whyNikescrapped a television commercial for their trainer shoes. And a bizarre tale it is too. It seemsNikewent to a lot of trouble and dollars to make a commercial in Africa for American audiences.The idea was to have a group of Masai warriors running through the bush wearingNiketrainers and endorsing the firm's product in between spearing passing antelopes.A grumpy looking warrior fronts the screen, mutters something in his native dialect and a translation appears on the screen ""Just do it", which isNikeAmerica's slogan.Unfortunately that is not quite what the warrior actually said.Freely translated, the grumpy-looking warrior said: ""These are horrid shoes and they aren't big enough."As luck would have it, one of the few people outside Africa who spoke the warrior's language just happened to see the commercial at its first _ and only _ showing. End of commercial. Exit sullen natives.Exit red-faced ad makers.

Email_Body: Bo knows doubt.     Bo knows fear.     His future?     Bo can't know.     Until recently, Bo Jackson seemed an unlimited and indestructible athlete. Fast as the Gulf wind, strong as a bull, and overendowed by the athletic gods. Star of the NFL, MLB andNike.Able to slug baseballs farther than anybody, and run with footballs as few have, and mesmerize a public that couldn't get enough of watching him.      Bo, the super sneaker salesman.     Bo, the Royals slugger.     Bo, the Raiders racer.     But suddenly, and shockingly, Bo Jackson's mortality surfaced.  Turns out, he's human. Like you, like me, the 225-pound multisport Adonis is breakable. Wearing his black No. 34 football jersey, Jackson mangled a hip while straining for a first down in a Los Angeles Raiders playoff game Jan. 13. It may wind up being the kryptonite for this Superman.     Kansas City Royals teammate George Brett, a witness as Bo bounded away from baseball spring training on crutches, detected a "Man, I'm scared" look in Jackson eyes that have forever been cool, clever and cocksure. "Bo's never thought there was anything he couldn't do," Brett said, "but now he's worried he may never play again."     Bo is 28.     I was in the L.A. Coliseum the afternoon Jackson went down against the Cincinnati Bengals. Carted away, he gave a thumbs-up, promising to "definitely be in Buffalo" for the following week's AFC Championship Game. I believed him.     Bo didn't make it. He may never. On Monday, Jackson vowed to play baseball in the 1991 season. This time, I don't believe him. You wonder, does Bo believe Bo? Royals management thinks so little of his recuperative chances that Jackson's $ 2,375,000 contract was voided Monday, and Kansas City general manager Herk Robinson made him available to major-league rivals for the $ 1 waiver price.     A buck for Bo.     This is not a tragedy to rival Lou Gehrig's disease, or golfer Tony Lema's death in a plane crash, or George Gipp being struck down at Notre Dame. No matter what happens, Bo Jackson should be rich, famous, marketable and able to do almost anything but play football and baseball. He'll still have a good wife, and wonderful kids.     But when you're Superman, you expect to always leap tall buildings. I predict Jackson will work inhumanly hard, sweating through rehab, trying to prove the Royals wrong, along with anybody else who suggests he's finished. Bo is a different breed, and he has spent a young lifetime getting kicks out of doing the unforecastable thing.     Critics said Jackson would never make it in professional baseball because he struck out in more than half his at-bats at Auburn University. We now know different. Bo kept on whiffing, but my how he has whacked the ball in the American League.     Tampa Bay made Bo its No. 1 pick in the NFL draft, and voices kept saying that Jackson "had to play." Again, he proved us wrong, and took delight in doing it. Bo chose baseball, but once the Bucs were out of his life, the football thoughts returned.     People like me said Jackson would never be able to play both major-league baseball and in the National Football League. It has been a stretch, and not totally satisfactory for either the Royals or Raiders, but Bo has come remarkably close to pulling it off.     Two months ago, when Jackson crumbled in Los Angeles, it seemed time for the young multimillionaire to loosen hisNikesand make a choice. Do one sport, but not both. Enough of the carnival act, of being part-Royal and part-Raider. Bo's sensible decision had to be baseball, where his career might last another 10 years, if he could give up his combative "hobby" of football.     Now, the choice may be gone.     I don't have tears in my eyes, but instead there's an emptiness in my stomach. There is a wide-bodied loss. Bo Jackson has unique appeal. He puts paying fannies into ballpark seats. AskNikehow he sells. Sports needs characters, and superhuman talents. Bo has been a little of both. I always wondered how good a baseball player might he be if he would give up football? Or how marvelous a Raider would he become if football was his only game?     We may never know.     Bo may never know.

Email_Body: So I am about to turn Jack Benny's eternal age.     To perhaps half the readers of the column, this disclosure will be significant only in its grand insignificance, a laughable announcement.     They have known the other side of 39 and then some for a while now and live with restraint and dignity, on fixed incomes usually, while sneering at Aging Boomers.     Go ahead. You have plenty of company.      The advertising mavens think people like me are such saps that all , they have to do is make up some snappy ad and we'll just dash out and slap down our Visa card for lineless bifocals, Lycra tights and Gap turtlenecks anything to prop up our delusion that we are exempt from the toll of years.     You can be sure, though, that this advertising rubbish has had no impact on me.     This, you will see, is another form of delusion.     Picture it: I was window-shopping in the local sports shop. The first thing I did was snap up one of those costumes fit for wearing while suffering muscle pulls and trying to fool the years.     Then I spied the poster. Because there is such a thing in the world as principle, I passed up the impulse to buy it although it turned out the poster wasn't for sale.     So I just memorized the way it looked.     The poster, actually an ad forNike,featured a nearly life-sized black and white '50s-era photo of a kid in pigtails who could have been Beaver's first girlfriend.     Superimposed over the photo was a string of words about how this was really a picture of what a 40-year-old woman looks like.     The message this medium conveyed was that cliche, dusted off and dressed up to be hip, about how you're only as old as you feel.  And how you can run that marathon and overhaul your lumpy self, even if you are 40.     This is the sort of advice that desperate Aging Boomers really need to hear anything to spend money and to dress like Jimmy Connors, who did so remarkably well, for a 39-year-old, at the U.S.  Open last week.     If I get it right, the advertising mavens are telling me I should run, swim, bike, jump, hop, swing, kick, pitch, punt, row, lift, squeeze, push, pull, stretch, lean, throw, flex, walk, skate and skip into new shape and strength.     I have been trying to do that. People who know my former, lumpy self would hardly recognize me now.     But guess what else happened?     I ran into the one hitch that the people atNikenever tell you about.     I was so busy exercising, there wasn't time for anything else. Not watching a movie or writing a book or dreaming a dream or listening to a friend, not sweeping the floor, doing the laundry, or contemplating the future and my place in it.     This is a terrible discovery, worse than confronting crow's feet or sagging skin.     The older you get, the less time you have to do things.     When you're 20, life is a limitless vista, a free lunch, a Monopoly game where the bad plays don't count.     When you're 40, you can make a list of the bad plays already and you wish somebody would fold up the game board and pull out, maybe, Trivial Pursuit. You've done pretty well at that, metaphorically speaking.     You start making lists of the trips you want to take, the people you want to meet, the jobs you'd rather have. You start considering a new set of choices, and this time, you vow to get them right.     You start picturing yourself with the lines and the creases that are coming regardless. And you don't hesitate to get annoyed at people whom you suspect are wasting your time including those advertising mavens who concoct clever ads to sell $ 100Nikeshoes to Aging Boomers and are probably already working on ads to sell us workout shoes for our retirement, if we have any money left then.     This, then, is the gift that comes when you turn Jack Benny's eternal age: an awareness of time, how it is a resource no longer for wasting, how it moves faster than you, until there is no more.     Perhaps this is why everybody, even couch potatoes, wears running shoes: to fool ourselves into thinking we can keep up.

Email_Body: There's no trick to finding the Georgia Dome these days. It finds you. Nine months ago the $ 210 million project was merely a few concrete footings. Now much of the Dome's outside structure rises dramatically out of what last year was a vacant lot. On May 1, they start on the roof.By February, 1992, the exterior will be watertight. Hey, 25 years later, they can't even say that about Atlanta-Fulton County Stadium. . . . Georgia Dome officials even found two suites recently they didn't know existed. Architects had planned for four owner suites - two upper level and two lower level - but only two are needed. Dome marketing director Dennis Berkholtz leased the newly discovered ones for $ 80,000 each. . . . Go figure: The Georgia Dome still has a dirt floor and cannot be used. Atlanta-Fulton County Stadium puts tons of dirt over it's sodded grass to hold a motocross Saturday night.SUPER BUDGET: How big has "The Super Show" become? Exhibit A: The Nikepeople have a $ 6 million budget just for this week's events at the Georgia World Congress Center. Things are so secretive regardingNike's presentation Thursday that a security guard has been stationed next to the escalator leading to the ballroom level, under an elaborateNike archway. Workers in the area assembling booths must wear ID bracelets. . . . Exhibit B: No other trade show in the nation requires what this one does. All current exhibitors must pay for next year's space before they leave on Feb. 24, allowing show organizers to draw interest on the money.KISSING BANDIT: To the tune of "Brick House" by the Commodores, mascot Harry the Hawk came out during a timeout dressed as a buxom blonde and swaggered up to NBA official Dick Bavetta at last Saturday night's Hawks-Sonics game. Locking up with Harry in a sudden embrace, Bavetta laid one emphatically on the mascot's kisser. When razzed by players on the Hawks bench, Bavetta glanced over to them and said, "Hey, it's lonely on the road." . . . Hawks trainer Joe O'Toole has lost 40 pounds over a period of less than three months and is down to about 180 - no small feat considering the caloric nightmare of food on the road. It didn't come without a struggle. O'Toole's beloved afternoon ice-cream snacks are pretty much history, and he walks at least 40 minutes a day. On a recent trip to San Francisco O'Toole walked from Fisherman's Wharf across the Golden Gate Bridge and back, a distance of about nine miles, in 3 1/2 hours. . . . Somebody forgot to tell Kevin Loughery he isn't a head coach anymore. It's his voice, not Bob Weiss's, that carries from the Hawks bench. . . . Kelly Freeman, Miss Augusta, sang the national anthem Saturday night. So why were there are few catcalls when she was introduced to The Omni crowd? Mistakenly, she was referred to as Miss AuguIN THE TRENCHES: Atlanta Falcons offensive guard John Scully, who studies battles and war strategy in his spare time, has difficulty getting a feel for the Persian Gulf conflict. "It's kind of hard to develop a mental picture," said Scully, who has a model of the Battle of Murfreesboro set up in his house. "You don't even know the disposition of troops on the border. It's truly desert warfare. The only thing you could compare it with is the North African campaign during World War II, where logistics and supplies were really how campaigns were won or lost. It's difficult to defend in the desert because it's a featureless terrain. There's no place to hide. The attacker usually is rewarded." . . . Todd Marinovich, the banished Southern Cal quarterback, still has a lifestyle unbalanced from most folks. He's never tried a Big Mac, and they've never tried cocaine. . . . A nickname that should have stuck by now for a player who moves swiftly, sometimes under enemy defenses, and occasionally inflicts great damage from the perimeter: Scud Webb. . . . Hard to believe: Dunwoody tour golfer Tim Simpson, during a recent TV interview, claiming not to be bothered if people fail to recognize his talent. Email_Body: The sporting goods industry resembles Dominique Wilkins's missed slam-dunk in this year's NBA All-Star game: There's still plenty of spring in its legs, but maybe not what there used to be.That was the message, in effect, that John D. Riddle, president of the Sporting Goods Manufacturers Association, deliverd to analysts Wednesday. They were gathered at the Georgia World Congress Center on the eve of the industry's annual Super Show mega-convention. Mr. Riddle said the $ 30 billion industry grew 6 percent last year - good, compared with the 2 percent overall growth of U.S. manufacturing, but sharply down from the double-digit growth in the 1980s."Manufacturers are prepared for a good, but by no means great, year," said Mr. Riddle, who attributed the slowdown to the recession and tight credit.Sales growth this year will be driven by sports apparel and equipment for tennis, bowling and billiards, Mr. Riddle said, estimating 8 percent increases.In previous years, athletic shoes put the bounce in the industry's step. But shoe sales may rise only 6 percent this year, he predicted.Apparel sales, worth $ 13.6 billion, will eclipse total sales for all sporting equipment at $ 10.9 billion, he predicted.; Pumping it upAthletic shoe manufacturers, meanwhile, have stepped up rivalries to increase their sales.No. 2 Reebok three weeks ago launched its most agressive advertising effort yet, attacking No. 1Nikewith a $ 20 million campaign using the slogan "Pump up, and air out."Nikecried foul, claiming Reebok was abusingNikeendorsers by mentioning them in Reebok's ads.Reebok Chairman Paul Fireman told analysts Wednesday the company plans to step up the attack, pumping an additional $ 15 million into its ad budget this year, for a total of $ 70 million.Meanwhile, Reebok said it plans to buy up 21.3 percent of its outstanding common stock for $ 396 million. As part of the deal, Pentland Group PLC will reduce its stake in Reebok to 13 percent from 31.6 percent.

Email_Body: Move over, Michael. Here comes Bo.Creating a natural marketing tie-in with basketball star and fellow Nikepitchman Michael Jordan of the Chicago Bulls, outfielder Bo Jackson signed with the Chicago White Sox on Wednesday. "It's not the fame, it's not the money, it's the chance to go out and get the world championship," said Jackson, who signed a one-year contract.However, Toronto Blue Jays general manager Pat Gillick said he thinks an association withNikeinfluenced Jackson's decision as much as the White Sox's status as contenders in the American League West."The wholeNikedeal was in Chicago. With him and Jordan owned by the same company, there is so much imagination that can come out of something like that," Gillick said.Gillick's Blue Jays and the Atlanta Braves were the other two clubs considered seriously by Jackson, a free agent after his release by the Kansas City Royals because of a hip injury sustained in last season's NFL playoffs."We weren't able to get into it at all," said Braves general manager John Schuerholz. "Richard Woods Jackson's agent called me Tuesday night to tell me things were moving pretty rapidly. He didn't tell me a signing was imminent. But there was nothing we could do about it."Jackson's salary will depend on how much he is able to play. The White Sox have options for 1992 and 1993. The first option will be automatic if Jackson is activated for at least 40 games this season. The White Sox must pick up the second option if Jackson plays at least 125 games in 1992.Jackson will earn $ 10,000 for each game played this season or a total of $ 700,000, whichever is greater. If he fulfills all performance bonuses over the next three seasons, he will make $ 8.1 million. Bonuses earned will automatically be included in the next season's base salary.The contract does not prohibit Jackson from fulfilling the final year of his $ 7.4 million contract with the NFL's Los Angeles Raiders if his health permits.

Email_Body: The shoemakerNikeInc. nosed out fragrance maker Calvin Klein as the sponsor of the most popular print advertising campaign of 1990, according to a consumer survey of 24,000 people released Sunday by Video Storyboard Tests Inc.TheNikeprint ads last year included a campaign that featured basketball star Michael Jordan and filmmaker Spike Lee.The remaining Top 10, in order, were: Camel cigarettes, Revlon, Absolut vodka, Infiniti cars, Marlboro cigarettes, Guess apparel, Ford automobiles and trucks and Maybelline cosmetics. BAT DANGER: Lots of children get hurt batting in baseball each year, and a Roanoke, Va., woman is doing something about it.Lorine S. Caveness 14 years ago founded Home Safe Face Guards to make plastic shields to protect the batter's face from a pitched ball. She began developing the guard in 1968 for her son. The guard attaches to the sides of a standard batting helmet, covering the chin to the tip of the nose. The eyes are exposed, but a guard keeps the ball from them.The Consumer Product Safety Commission estimates that 5,500 baseball- related eye injuries were treated in hospital emergency rooms in 1989. Another study found 42,000 facial injuries each year in amateur baseball, with 18,000 for players age 5 to 18.Nationally, Little League and Dixie Youth Baseball require helmets but not masks. However, Little League officials in Marietta, Ga., do require face masks. One coach, Richard Hilton, described the face mask as "the best piece of safety equipment in Little League" since the helmet. The guards cost $ 13 each. A wire face guard made by Schutt Manufacturing of Litchfield, Ill., is available at sports stores.CAT DANGER: One in five sick cats has one of two deadly diseases, feline leukemia or a more recently identified virus similar to AIDS in humans, according to a new study. IDEXX Corp. of Portland, Ore., surveyed 1,500 veterinary clinics in the United States and covered 27,000 sick cats. The study showed that 7.4 percent of the cats suffered from feline immunodeficiency virus, or FIV, and 13.3 percent suffered from feline leukemia, a similar disease that also suppresses the ability of cats to fight off disease.Compiled from wire reports

Chad Carithers scored 16 goals to lead the Gladiators to first place in theNikeunder-19 indoor tournament last week at The Soccer Academy in Lilburn. The Gladiators defeated Phoenix 9-0 in the championship game."This was our best tournament in the seven years of theNike," said Steve Keiss, tournament director. "We had no ejections, all games were played in the proper spirit, and fans, players and officials all had a tremendous time." The Most Valuable Player was Troy Wood of the Steamers '75, whose team was eliminated 4-2 in the semifinals by the Gladiators. Steve Brandt of Chelsea Villa, which lost 3-0 in the semifinals to Phoenix, was named Best Defender. John Brown of Chelsea Villa was voted Most Sportsmanlike. Michael Rachael of Phoenix and Mark Albertus of the Gladiators were voted Best Goalkeepers.The 17-team tournament was divided into three divisions. Each division played a round-robin format to decide who reached the playoff round. The top two teams in each division and the next two teams with the best record qualified.In the quarterfinals: Phoenix beat the Grasshoppers 4-3; Chelsea Villa beat the Homeless Millionaires 6-3; the Gladiators topped the Yellow Bellies 10-2; and the Steamers downed the Smart Wunz 6-2. . . .Two local women's teams lost in the Region III finals in Charleston, S.C., last week. In the over-30 division, Poco Loco of Texas defeated the Atlanta Breeze 6-5 on penalty kicks. In the open division, North Texas defeated Soccer Warehouse 5-1. . . .The under-12 Brookwood Steamers lost to the Gadsden, Ala., Hawks in a tournament played at Canterbury Park in Kennesaw. The game was tied 1-1 and the Steamers lost on the fifth penalty kick. . . .The Atlanta Express, the local team competing in the Sunbelt Independent Soccer League, is in third place in the Southeast Division after a 4-3 victory over the Atlanta Quicksilver. David Smith, an Atlanta Attack player, got the winning goal - his second of the game.Other Express goals came from Richard Taylor and Selby Neese. The Quicksilver got goals from Scott Smith, Tracy Crouch and Gilberto Ramirez.The Express (1-2) trails undefeated Memphis and Arkansas (3-0) in outdoors play. The Express has added Greg Sheen of the Attack and Mark Gailey, the starting goalkeeper for the University of North Carolina.The two teams meet three more times this season.
email_title: SOCCER NOTES; Carithers leads Gladiators to title inNiketourney

Email_Body: Being picked No. 2 overall by New Jersey rather than No. 3 by Sacramento not only means a bigger NBA contract for Kenny Anderson, it also means a bigger shoe contract.From a shoe marketing standpoint, a would-be pitchman's earning potential is far greater in the New York-New Jersey area than in Sacramento. Officials atNikeconfirmed the company is negotiating to add Anderson to its stable of marquee NBA talent, which includes Michael Jordan, and that he is now in position to probably demand a better shoe deal.Anderson can expect to receive a yearly shoe contract for about $ 400,000 playing in New Jersey, versus $ 300,000 in the smaller Sacramento market."I think it's much harder to market a guy in Sacramento," said Fred Schreyer,Nike'sdirector of sports marketing. "You'll be on a bad team that no one is ever going to see. While New Jersey isn't a great team and no one will see them much, either, you do have the New Jersey-New York thing and Kenny being a New York schoolboy legend."Sports agent Leigh Steinberg, who represents many of the top NFL quarterbacks, is making his first venture into the basketball arena as the agent for Nevada-Las Vegas guard Greg Anthony. Steinberg's football clients include Warren Moon, Troy Aikman and Jeff George. basketball; personalities; advertising; salaries

Email_Body: Kenny Anderson is the latestNikepitchman. The former Georgia Tech star has signed a multi-year deal, joining such marquee NBA players as Michael Jordan, David Robinson and Charles Barkley. Converse and Reebok were the other finalists for Anderson's endorsement.Nikeofficials plan to feature Anderson on a national television campaign this season. Anderson, a New York schoolboy legend, was selected No. 2 overall by the New Jersey Nets in last month's NBA draft.Richard Howell, who represents Anderson, said the contract forbids disclosure of financial terms or length. However, industry officials said after the draft that Anderson would probably receive a shoe contract for about $ 400,000 a year."We're obviously very pleased with it," Howell said. "You'll be seeing him on some ads."As for Anderson's playing contract, Howell said he has had one "philosophical" meeting with Nets officials and has another meeting scheduled within the next two weeks.
