Nancy Daniels, a former star runner and an exercise physiologist for theNikecompetitive team, said Wednesday she has been hired as the University of South Florida's first full-time cross country and track assistant.     "I'm really excited to be here; I used to run Division I and I'm excited to be back to Division I in a big way," Daniels said.     Daniels had been informally assisting her husband, Jack, at Cortland State, N.Y., since 1986. The women's team there won the NCAA Division III cross-country championships in 1989 and 1990 and the indoor track title in 1990-91.      "We struggled with it for a week," Daniels said of leaving New York and her husband, who will retire from coaching at the end of this school year.     USF coach Bob Braman, whohas run both the men's and women's programs over the years, echoed those sentiments.     "She's got the credentials to really help us," he said. "Her teams were Division III, but they were good enough to be top 10 in Division I. She's going to be a strong draw for us and she's strong in areas I'm not."     Daniels, 32, formerly Nancy Scardina, was one of the University of New Hampshire's best runners ever. She led the team to the NCAA cross-country championships in 1981 and to the NCAA outdoor track championships in 1982. In 1988, she qualified for the U.S.  Olympic Trials in the marathon.     She then worked physiologically and nutritionally with the nation's premier runners, including Mary Decker and Joan Benoit while atNike'sAthletes West from 1983-86. She also has published numerous papers on the exercise physiology of runners.     "That's helped," she said. "I like giving people facts about running and see their eyes open. People don't like to believe you, but they can't dispute scientific facts and say, "That's not what my high school coach told me.' I really love working with the kids."     The USF women's program, just four years old, won its first cross-country title of any kind, the Sun Belt Conference crown, last fall under part-time assistant Judy Bogenschutz. Bogenschutz chose not to return and to concentrate on her running career.     This year, track will officially become a varsity sport at USF and the budget for men's and women's cross country and track will double, from $ 110,000 to $ 215,000. Scholarships will be increased from four to seven for the men and the women alike.

If the prospect of Thanksgiving overindulgence leaves you feeling guilty, here's one way to ease a calorie-counting conscience and help others, too.     On Thanksgiving morning, Tuff Stuff exercise coordinators Joan Kilpatrick and Susan Harrod will conduct a special bench workout at Shore Acres Community Center. A donation of one non-perishable food item gets you in the class. Bring four more and you'll be eligible for door prizes that include exercise tapes, massages, pastries, free Tuff Stuff classes andNikesneakers.    If that's not enough, consider this: The food you bring will help fill the cupboards of the St. Petersburg Free Clinic Food Bank and feed those who won't have the same opportunities to indulge during the holiday season.     "I think it will be particularly helpful this year because the need is so great," said Sister Margaret Freeman, executive director of St.  Petersburg's Free Clinic. "They (Kilpatrick and Harrod) are doing a great job of creating interest."      The workout began six years ago and has become a Shore Acres tradition. Last year, 102 participants brought so much food it took four cars to haul it away. Harrod said the class began as a way to get people exercising during the holidays. A food drive was added the following year.     "We started going crazy (with activities)," Harrod said.     The workout got bigger and busier every Thanksgiving.     This year, the workout's door prizes are donated by radio stations, national exercise programs and local businesses. A chef will prepare strudels and Napoleons on site during the workout, then donate them as prizes. David Pittman will bring in a sound system for an added boost.   "It's kind of exciting," Harrod said. "The person who donates the most canned goods we crown her the Can Queen. Last year, the Can Queen brought in something like 70 cans."     Being crowned queen has benefits. This year's prize package includes a pair ofNikes,a leotard and three months of Tuff Stuff classes.     But what happens if the person bringing the most cans is male?     "He's still the Can Queen," Harrod said. "That's what the sash says."      Despite the jovial atmosphere, Harrod and Kilpatrick are serious about their mission. Kilpatrick said she hopes participants will try to bring the foods needed most. Peanut butter, jelly, rice, soup, beans, powdered milk, dry cereal, canned meats and vegetables, dried or canned fruits, and boxed macaroni and cheese head the list.  If possible, bring the food in large paper bags that can be reused when the food is distributed.     Items with limited value are gourmet foods, such as caviar; foods that require added meat or have an expired freshness date; refrigerated products; and foods that must be prepared in a microwave. The Food Bank already has a good supply of baby food.   If the past is any indication, the class should fill up quickly. Harrod said about 85 benches from community centers throughout St.  Petersburg have been brought in for the step up/step down workout. Because each person needs a bench, the class size is limited to the number of benches.     What makes the workout so popular? "I think it's just that there's nothing to do (on Thanksgiving morning)," Harrod said, "and plus, they feel guilty (about overeating)."

BY JOYCE CARTERThe Globe and MailCOLE-Haan, the giant international shoe and handbag concern, opens itsfirst Canadian store to the public Saturday at 101 Bloor West. To judge by the furnishings, attention to detail is foremost in theminds of the principles. The ceilings have domed centres with hand-castbas-relief faces of foxes, mountain lions and the like. Display cases havebands of other hand-carved animals."They were done as a tribute to Canada, to say thank you to Toronto forwelcoming us," explains Cathy Taylor, the firm's vice-president retail.She was born and raised here and admits to a lingering fondness for herhome town, "so I've been looking at Toronto for the past five years," witha view of just such a store."But the timing has to be right and you must have the right location,"so they waited until the prime corner site became available. Only then didBarton A. Forbes of Forbes Associates, Falmouth, Maine, get started on thedesign, a task he's repeated a dozen times for flagship stores around theworld, including Beverly Hills, New York, Florence and Tokyo.The company, which projects sales of $150-million U.S. in the comingyear, is based in Yarmouth, Maine. Shoes, handbags and accessories(including cabin trunks for luxury liners) are produced in the UnitedStates, Italy, England, Brazil and Spain.Speaking of the shoes, Ms Taylor says "we are specialists in fitting,we are very confident in our fit. Americans understand this, we usedifferent lasts than they do in Italy. Italian lasts are more tapered fromthe ball of the foot to the toe, we make a fuller toe. Italian lasts areshallow at the toe, ours are much higher for comfort."That doesn't mean they sacrifice style. For all the firm has been ownedbyNikeInc. since 1988, there's no sign of the runners in the Cole-Haanstores. "We operate as two separate companies. We do have a group ofproducts - Tensile Air - which putsNiketechnology into a dress shoe."The examples look just like any other street shoes but inside, they'recushioned "they have the air built in, they will never deflate."That's just one group among many: everything from classic Americancountry footwear to sleek Italian slip-ons. Many of the shoes, as well ashandbags, come in woven leather and the same technique is applied to satinfor the perfect tuxedo pumps.Prices, she figures, will be about 17 per cent higher than in theUnited States, to cover the difference in the dollar and the higher costof doing business here. Stock for their Canadian wholesale accounts willbe housed in the basement. ("No, I don't think that makes us competitorswith stores like Harry Rosen, we've been selling to him for years. It justmeans greater recognition of our name.")There are at present no plans to open other Canadian stores. "You'vegot to have a starting point. You've got to do well before you go on. Thisis the city we have confidence in now. We believe very strongly inCanada."

By EDWARD CLIFFORDSOONER or later, your rug rats will try to coerce you into buying $109sneakers so that they can hold up their heads - and feet - with pride.Before succumbing to the natural parental tendency to give Ashley orJustin the best, pause. Wouldn't it be better to give them $23 K martfootwear, invest the savings in shares of Reebok International Ltd. ofStoughton, Mass., and let other parents pay for your kids' collegeeducation?It may sound cruel to a child with a two-week time horizon, butinvestors with a longer view will benefit from an understanding of theshoe industry. Leisure shoes are popular with all age groups. Even senior adults liketo have nifty, new-technology gear, apparently ignoring the adage,"comfortable as an old shoe."There's not much difference between shoes. If they fit and feel good,who cares what name they carry? Lots of people obviously care a lot.Reebok is suing other companies for copyright infringement. It claimsit is the sole owner of the "pump" technology. Put the shoe on, pump inair for a tight fit, and win a gold medal.In the mid-1950s, European ski boots that pioneered the technology wereavailable in North America - although we can remember one broken anklethat they did not prevent.The shoe business is basically an advertising game. The company withthe best marketing strategy wins, and right now Reebok is the leader.Its shares trade at $30.75 (U.S.) in New York, an amazing recovery fromthe 52-week low of $8.87. Can it go any higher?Yes, says Value Line Inc. of New York. Reebok has introduced a productknown as Blacktop, a shoe for youngsters who play hockey, baseball,football and basketball on driveways and roads.Naturally, kids who love asphalt sports will play them, no matter whatthey wear on their feet. Blacktop shoes should appeal to the ones whodon't, but pretend they do.Reebok's competitors include the following:L.A. Gear Inc. of Los Angeles. It was saved from bankruptcy this weekby selling $100-million worth of shares to Trefoil Capital Investors. DoesTrefoil have marketing smarts? Probably not, but L.A. Gear does have adistribution system reaching into 100 countries, and has a cool image thatmight serve it well in Eastern European markets.NikeInc. of Beaverton, Ore. Volatile stock, and has a problem with itsname. Is it Ny-kee? Knee-kee? Neeck? OrNike, as in like? One basic rulefor investors is to stay away from shares of companies that have namesthey cannot pronounce.Stride Rite Corp. of Cambridge, Mass. This company makes the Keds line.Your curtain-crawlers may hate them, but Keds sneakers work just as wellas Reeboks.Wolverine World Wide Corp. of Rockford, Minn. Many upscale householdsin North America have at least one pair of its products: Hush Puppies andBrooks, for example. With quality brand names and licencing agreements inthe world's most prosperous markets, executives can farm out manufacturingto low-cost countries and be home in time for dinner.While many North American companies and their employees decry U.S.efforts to create a Western Hemisphere free-trade zone, the shoe businessshould benefit. Instead of out-sourcing manufacturing to Asia, it can bebrought closer to markets, and everybody, including Canadian investors andconsumers, wins.

BY SUEIN L. HWANGThe Wall Street JournalNew YorkFORGET leg lifts and abdominal crunches. Today's aerobics instructors areturning to reggae, tai chi, hip hop and even prayer to lure aging babyboomers back into the fold."You wouldn't believe the goofy stuff we've seen," says Gordie Nye,marketing director for Reebok International Ltd., which is always on thelookout for new fitness routines that it can promote. Ten years ago, it took little more than a slim figure, a loud voice anda disco beat to get fat-obsessed yuppies to go for the burn. Aerobicsroutines, the invention of a California housewife, began with the simplemarriage of music and calisthenics. Aerobics introduced a generation ofwomen to the world of fitness and created a $1-billion (U.S.) market.Now, the recession, concern about possible injury and general boredomwith aerobics have led to a slide in participation. A recent survey in theUnited States by the National Sporting Goods Association found that thenumber of people performing aerobics more than once in the past year hasfallen 2.8 per cent since 1985 and sales of aerobics footwear in 1990dropped to 9.8 million pairs from 10.8 million in 1986.Many sports researchers believe the aerobics boom has come and gone.Many of the women who started working out in aerobics classes have beenlured away by stair-climbing machines, Rollerblading and other forms ofexercise."There's a faddist group among active people and they've already goneon to a third and fourth thing," says Thomas Doyle, research director atthe National Sporting Goods Association.But even skeptics concede that the aerobics industry has succeeded inmaintaining a loyal following by reinventing itself when necessary.Aerobics routines, at one time little more than a series of kicks andjumps, have grown more sophisticated, integrating jazzier moves and safer"low-impact" approaches.Some ambitious entrepreneurs are promoting what they hope will be thenext successful incarnation of aerobics. Reebok succeeded in promotingstep aerobics - stepping on and off an elevated bench - and now it iswilling to invest millions of dollars on promotion if it can come up witha promising new form of exercise that will help sell sportswear.What does it take to gain attention? First, find a gimmick. Reebok, ofCanton, Mass., experimented with a California-born notion calledKneedspeed, in which the exerciser makes skating motions on a piece oflinoleum in stocking feet. But the company finally abandoned the conceptbecause it didn't seem to have strong appeal.In Washington, D.C., the Synergy Studio offers a "holistic" approach."There's a spiritual need for people to connect with their bodies," saysRoger Piantadosi, co-owner of the studio.Classes begin with meditative quiet and are designed around fivenatural elements, such as water. In one recent class, a group of mostlyaffluent professionals in their 30s pounded their bare feet to the beat ofAfrican drums and slapped their stomachs while emitting hoarse grunts."Around the fire and the Earth," commanded instructor Charmaine Schore asthe women shook convulsively while lying on their backs. "Draw the spiritto you!"Synergy Studio grossed $195,000 in 1990, up 30 per cent from the yearbefore, and it now has plans to develop videos and train more instructors.Others take a celestial approach.As instructor Jeannie Blocher leads a class at Body & Soul MinistriesInc. in Germantown, Md., the words to a song blare out: "It won't be long'til we see Jesus. It won't be long 'til He'll be here, yeah, yeah."This non-profit program counts more than 200 aerobics teachers in itsnon-denominational clergy. Ms. Blocher hopes to expand the program andplans a video release. "I would like to see it spread and just continue asthe Lord wishes," says the 42-year-old mother of three. "We call ourselvesBody and Soul Missionaries."Deferring to the aging of their target market, many programs haveeliminated difficult jumping or kicking moves while focusing on new ethnicbeats. Esther Gutierrez-Sloan, a Colombian immigrant and president ofSalsarobics Inc., hopes her Latin-styled aerobics will help her rumbaright past the competition.The former computer consultant is looking for outside investors tofinance an ambitious business plan that includes franchises and a line ofworkout wear. "The music's very unique and culturally educational," shesays. "And it makes women feel sensual."Not everybody's convinced that new forms of aerobics will have mucheffect on demand. "Yes, you're going to bring in different kinds ofpeople," says Kathie Davis, executive director of IDEA, an industry group."But you aren't going to have a massive effect on the numbers."Rather than promote specialized aerobics routines, Reebok rivalNikeInc. is focusing on the versatility of its aerobics shoes.Nike, of Beaverton, Ore., says sales of its cross-training shoes are up"very significantly" from past years and it has started a marketingcampaign featuring its Elite aerobic shoes in a variety of workouts."Women do many things in their lives and a step-aerobics shoe isn'tthat uniquely different" from other aerobics shoes, saysNike'saerobicsapparel marketing manager. "We can't all own five pairs of shoes."Reprinted with permission of The Wall Street Journal1991 Dow Jones & Co. Inc., all rights reserved

BY MARTY YORKIS the Rocket on the verge of flying off to the National Football League?Well, one of the premier football reporters in the United States istelling his viewers and readers that he has definite and irrefutableinformation that Raghib Ismail - otherwise known as the Rocket - will beemployed in the NFL by next season."And maybe even before the end of this NFL season," Fred Edelstein saidin a telephone interview yesterday. "Every piece of information I have indicates that the length ofRocket's career with the Toronto Argonauts will be exactly one season."He's on his way to the Los Angeles Raiders. I wouldn't be surprised,in fact, if the Raiders have him in a uniform by next month."Edelstein's track record on football scoops is outstanding. Viewers ofhis weekly program on ESPN and readers of the well-circulated EdelsteinPro Football Letter can attest to that.And Don Crump didn't do much to dispel Edelstein's information when Ispoke to him yesterday. In fact, the Canadian Football League commissionerbacked it up pretty well when he admitted that Argo governor Sue Waksrecently told him in an angry moment that club owner Bruce McNall wasconsidering the notion of sending Ismail to the Raiders."She said, 'Don't think Bruce won't send Rocket over to Al,' " Crumpsaid. "She meant Al, as in Al Davis (owner of the Raiders)."Who knows? If the Rocket leaves, maybe it'll be the start of a trendfor the CFL. Maybe a lot of big-name players will come over for one seasonand then go to the NFL."Reached in Los Angeles yesterday, Waks denied making any threats aboutIsmail to Crump. She also said Ismail has enjoyed his rookie season withthe Argos and that she would be "shocked" if he jumped to the Raidersafter the CFL season.Beverly Ballard, whom Ismail employs as a public-relations aide, echoedWaks's sentiments, saying that the Rocket intends to honour all fourseasons of his $18-million, Argonaut contract."But what you must understand," Edelstein said, "is that the NFL andthe CFL are leagues of denial. They deny everything. It's just a mode ofoperation for them. The fact that they deny something doesn't meananything."If I were operating the Argos, or if I were the Rocket, I'd deny thewhole thing, too. What purpose would it serve to confirm that he's leavingright before the playoffs?"But you can be sure it's happening. The Rocket will end up with about$6-million from McNall and will then accept a deal for a lot less fromDavis."Hey, if things were gangbusters in Toronto, if the Argos were sellingout the place and there was Argomania, it would be incumbent to continuethe deal. But being that none of this has happened, that the signingreally hasn't produced an outstanding television deal in the States,McNall has a nice parachute. He can just hand the Rocket over to theRaiders, and the Rocket won't mind, no matter what anyone else sayspublicly."In the latest edition of his publication, Edelstein wrote:"We hear Ismail is definitely hot on joining the Raiders next year. Oursources say he is having fun in Canada and that his relationship withBruce McNall is pretty good. But the CFL isn't the NFL and Rocketapparently misses the United States and the bright lights."Technically, players are not permitted to toil in the CFL and NFL inthe same year."But," Edelstein said, "when it becomes clear that Rocket's not comingback to Toronto and that he can get out of his CFL deal and his personalservices contract with McNall, it might be possible for the Raiders tomake a strong argument for getting him before the end of this year."From what I'm hearing out of the Raiders and people who are close tothe Rocket, this is the way it's going. I won't say it's a done deal, butunderstand that Al Davis is a shrewd man. He knows that the Rocket wantsto play in the NFL. He knows exactly to the dime how much McNall islosing. And he has a friendship with McNall in Los Angeles. He knows aboutthe escape clauses in Rocket's deal. This would not be a hostilesituation."Look, McNall has taken a bit of a bath on this thing. He took acourageous shot and it didn't really pay off the way he'd hoped. Theeasiest way to get out of this is to let Rocket go to the Raiders."By selecting Rocket in the last NFL draft, Al Davis has him exactlywhere he wants him. He's not going to bring in the Rocket and pay him $3-million a year. He doesn't have to. If he pays him any more than $1.5-million a year, I'd be shocked."Edelstein, incidentally, also reported that the Rocket has fired hisagent, Ed Abrams, over a decision to turn down aNikecommercial."Remember the recentNikecommercial with Bo Jackson dancing in abroadway show set?" Edelstein wrote. "Sources close to the Ismailsituation say that was supposed to be Rocket's commercial."The way we hear it, Rocket's mother was furious over the decision toblow offNikeand that the Rocket fired Abrams at his mother's urging."Preferred Management, a firm put together in part by former tennis starArthur Ashe, is now handling Ismail's finances. And the firm apparentlyhas close ties with Al Davis.

Email_Body: After market conditions and financing problems forced Hickok's Sporting Goods to close seven of its eight stores last month, three major creditors have dealt another blow to the 32-year-old business: an involuntary bankruptcy petition.Russell Corp.,NikeInc. and Reebok International filed the Chapter 7 petition against the Atlanta-based chain last Friday in the federal bankruptcy court for the northern district of Georgia. An involuntary Chapter 7 petition is a way creditors can force a business into bankruptcy, sell off its assets and get their money back. The petition states Hickok's and its parent firm, the Young Group Inc., owe the Russell Corp. $ 456,405,Nike$ 377,914 and Reebok International $ 891,491 for goods sold and delivered.Hickok's can either agree to the filing or try to fight it. Officials of the company said they were not prepared to comment.

Among the things Bo Jackson knows is how to give the media short rations. But it was a different story this week in Portland, Ore., where NikeInc., one of Jackson's many employers, decided to hold a news conference for high school journalists.With two of his own children watching from a balcony above, Jackson charmed the group with stories about his poor upbringing in rural Alabama and how he became rich and famous.His description of himself: "A nappy-headed kid who threw rocks better than some people could shoot a gun."; Caddyshack updateOccasionally, Sheryl Calcavecchia serves as caddie for her husband Mark at PGA Tour events. Noting that caddies' salaries often involve a percentage of the player's earnings, Mark observed:"She's the only one I know of who gets 100 percent."; The Doctor is out In his new book "Valvano: They Gave Me a Lifetime Contract, and Then They Declared Me Dead," former N.C. State basketball coach Jim Valvano explains why he's working as a TV announcer instead of a scout.In the late 1960s, while coaching the freshman team at Rutgers for Bill Foster, Valvano was sent to Long Island to check out a 6-foot-3 center touted by his brother. Valvano wasn't impressed, and here's the rest of the story:"Oh, the kid visited Rutgers on his own anyway and still seemed very interested, but I convinced Foster he couldn't play at our level and that we should go after another player named Alan Cotler."I lost Cotler to Penn. He's now a lawyer in Philadelphia. I lost track of the other kid. He was in Philly, too, but I think he became a doctor or something. You ever hear of him? Kid's name is Julius Erving."; A fresh startRudy Galindo is back at the U.S. Figure Skating Championships this year, but as a solo performer, rather than as a defending pairs champion, now that his former partner, Kristi Yamaguchi, has decided to concentrate on her solo career.Galindo has made one more adjustment in returning to singles for the first time since 1988: The spelling of his first name."I had changed it from Rudy to Rudi to match with Kristi," he said. "I'm into a new life and wanted everything to be fresh. So I'm back to Rudy."Galindo smiles, jokes and avoids saying anything that could be construed as sour grapes about the end of his pairing with Yamaguchi. But it's apparent he was hurt by the parting."It's kind of hard to be out there by yourself," Galindo said this week as he prepared for the start of the championships. "A few times, I went to grab Kristi's hand, and it was not there."; A K' for historyMark it down for posterity: Reid Ryan, 19-year-old son of Nolan, struck out the first batter he faced as a freshman at the University of Texas. The victim was a friend, Shayne Currin of Texas-Arlington, who spends his summers as bullpen catcher for the Texas Rangers.Reid Ryan's fastball was clocked in the 85 mph range, and his curveball was sharp as he pitched two innings, giving up one run.His dad didn't make the 150-mile trip from Alvin to Austin for the debut. But they'll see each other April 2 as opposing pitchers in an exhibition game.; He's learning fastFrom the Associated Press: When Wayne Gretzky turned 30 last month, Los Angeles Kings owner Bruce McNall gave him a horse they saw being born while they were at the Kentucky Derby.Gretzky and McNall are partners in the racing business, so Gretzky gave half back to McNall."I kept the front half, because I have learned that is the one that crosses the finish line first," joked Gretzky.; For the record . . .- Canada's Helen Kelesi rallied from a 3-0 deficit in the third set to upset third-seeded Jana Novotna 2-6, 7-6, 7-6 in the second round of the Virginia Slims of Chicago tennis tournament. No. 2 seed Katerina Maleeva of Bulgaria won her match against Ann Grossman.- Boris Becker beat Alexander Volkov 6-4, 3-6, 6-3 in the opening round of the Donnay Indoor Championship in Brussels, Belgium.- MaliVai Washington beat No. 16 seed Patrick McEnroe 6-0, 6-3 to advance to the quarterfinals of the $ 1 million U.S. Pro Indoor Tennis Championship in Philadelphia. (Complete tennis results, G9).- As many as 50 intramural male and female basketball teams from area colleges will meet in the Schick Super Hoops Regional Festival on Feb. 23 at Georgia State. The top male and female teams from the one-day tournament will play their championship games March 23 at The Omni as part of the Hawks-Miami game.Got a tip for Games & Faces? Give us a call on the message line at 222-2034.

The room was a blur of silk suits, highball glasses and eggrolls. The smell of merchandising was in the air."Ladies and gentlemen, it's my pleasure to introduce . . ."Of course, everybody at the Diversified Products (DP) cocktail and elbow-rubbing party Thursday night already knew which advertising vehicle was about to glide into the room. They had just seen a 10-minute video of Bo making a running catch in the outfield, Bo running for a touchdown, Bo breaking a bat over his knee, Bo scoring for Auburn, Bo doing that Arsenio thing, Bo filming aNikecommercial, Bo chugging a sports drink, Bo pushing AT&T and Cheerios and Pepsi. . . . "Bo Jackson!" DP president Cal James, completing his introduction, said to his audience of some 300 buyers at the Westin Peachtree Plaza Hotel.Jackson didn't so much glide into the room as he hobbled. He hobbled everywhere Thursday. The man of two sports and a zillion products was on crutches, the result of a hip injury last month in a Los Angeles Raiders playoff game. He will be on crutches for four weeks and may, according to a team doctor for his other employer, the Kansas City Royals, miss the season opener.But that didn't stop the dominant sports figure from enhancing his dominant marketing presence. Jackson flew into Atlanta from Auburn about 1 p.m. and in the next eight hours: (1) posed for publicity pictures with a young boy for the March of Dimes, (2) held a fireside chat with top Nikeexecutives and buyers in conjunction with the Super Show (he was not out for public or media display), (3) was introduced as the part owner and product spokesman for "Bo Med," a sports medicine line manufactured by Cramer Products, at a Georgia World Congress Center news conference, (4) was introduced in grand style at the Westin as part owner and chief spokesman for a new line of weightlifting equipment to be manufactured by DP.And then? Bo hobbled into a waiting limo at about 9 p.m. and was whisked to the airport, where he caught a return flight to Auburn. Why the rush?"He has a final exam to take tomorrow," said Susann McKee, who as an associate to Jackson's agent, Richard Woods, is charged with making sure Bo knows punctuality. "He's still working on his degree in child and family development."Bo needs no courses on income development. He will earn nearly $ 4 million in the next baseball and football seasons from the Royals ($ 2.375 million) and the Raiders ($ 1.6175 million) - and that is dwarfed by his off-field(s) earnings. Bo also has become quite polished on speaking to business executives.But he wouldn't discuss his injury Thursday. Royals trainer Steve Joyce said Jackson "isn't in the mild injury category." But when asked at the "Bo Med" gathering if he would be ready in time for the Royals season opener, Jackson said, "Man, I'm not here to talk about that."However, when explaining the advantages of his "Bo Med" ankle brace, Jackson joked, "We need to make one of these for a hip injury."More jokes flowed at the DP cocktail party. "I never knew DP made more weights than anybody in the country," Bo said. "See, that's something Bo doesn't know."

Jerry Tarkanian's friends are as diverse as they are loyal, their presence never more than a plane flight or phone call away. One owns a hair salon in Las Vegas. Another is the ex-husband of actress Diahann Carroll. Still another is aNikeexecutive who treads lightly anywhere near the NCAA. Others are more high profile - Bobby Knight and John Thompson, Dick Vitale, and a large number of coaches and scouts from the NBA.Yet as Nevada-Las Vegas pursues its second consecutive national championship this weekend in Indianapolis, Tarkanian's friends join his foes in wondering whether the NCAA's pursuit of the embattled coach - and anticipated sanctions at season's end - finally will prompt either his retirement or a departure to the NBA.Tark isn't telling.Perhaps it's because he himself is uncertain. On a given day, he professes to be a college coaching lifer, best suited for 40 minutes of frenzy and 30-odd games in a community that is appreciative, if not always approving, of his methods. (He has his detractors in Las Vegas, too.) Yet, on another day, Tarkanian ponders life after Vegas. "Maybe I should go to the NBA," he offers, frowning. "I don't need all this."At 60, Tarkanian clearly could rest on his coaching laurels. He has a career record of 811-145, is the second-winningest active Division I coach with 598 victories and has guided the Runnin' Rebels to 45 consecutive wins, one NCAA title and a second straight trip to the Final Four.He earns $ 203,000 in salary, $ 200,000 for a shoe contract and approximately $ 250,000 in free tickets to UNLV games. But he also has received 19 years of intense scrutiny and an assortment of penalties levied by the NCAA. This year, for instance, the Rebels were banned from appearing on television in 1992 and from participating in the postseason tournament, sanctions levied for violations dating back to the 1970s. The Rebels also are confronting 29 new allegations pertaining to the recruitment of New York prep star Lloyd Daniel, and reportedly are being investigated again for the recruitment of Los Angeles area prep star Ed O'Bannon."There is no program in the country that receives one-tenth the scrutiny we do," said Tarkanian. "Every player who leaves our program, they are trying to find something on. Our kids don't deserve this."But does Tarkanian? While his national image may be tarnished, he enjoys surprisingly strong support from unlikely sources, including Thompson, Knight, former UCLA coach John Wooden, former Cal coach Pete Newell, Seton Hall's P.J. Carlesimo and Utah's Rick Majerus. "I'm not anti-NCAA or anything," Majerus said recently, "but most of the coaches really like Tark. They think he's a good guy, a very decent person."Accordingly, those close to him are alert for signs of trouble, for any indications that the pressure finally has worn him down. Yet they say none is visible. Tarkanian has no hair to lose (he shaves his head), is not a heavy drinker and remains in relatively good shape for his years. Even his warm and engaging personality, they maintain, has remained consistent, as has his professional persona.While Tarkanian capitalizes on every opportunity to publicly flail the NCAA for its "McCarthyism" and plead his case to every reporter and for any interested publication, he responds to attacks on his program and his character with an amazing grace. For those who have yet to meet Tarkanian, the publicity staff schedules individual interviews like an all-comers' meet: You come to UNLV, you meet Tark. And even his most relentless critics relate how he continues to accept their phone calls, and often engages them in conversation."Jerry doesn't stay mad at anybody," said UNLV publicist Joe Hawk.A former Las Vegas Review-Journal reporter who wrote a damaging article in December 1989 about the high-priced cars several of the Rebel players were driving around town, Hawk subsequently was hired as the school's sports information director without opposition from Tarkanian. "It was a little awkward at first," said Hawk, "but Jerry's been very good to me."If anyone appears to have succumbed to the pressure, it would be a few of the players, though even this is arguable. After Hawk's story broke, Stacey Augmon and Larry Johnson initiated a team-wide ban on speaking to the media, though most of the Rebels relented during last year's postseason tournament. Augmon again refused to speak with reporters for most of this past season, despite encouragement to do so by Tarkanian.To a player, the Rebels remain true to their coach and his cause. At times, Johnson said, the controversy served only to strengthen their resolve and unite an already close-knit group. Before the tip-off of each game during the NCAA Tournament, for instance, the players embrace quietly, seemingly for themselves rather than for effect.Tarkanian, too, sees this, and it makes him wonder even further about the NBA. At UNLV, he rules not unlike Knight, Thompson, or any number of other major-college coaches. He controls. He dictates. He doesn't like a player, the player isn't around the following year. He doesn't like the schedule, the schedule is altered. He doesn't like the uniforms, new ones are on order.Can he claim this power in the NBA? Not likely, and he knows it."I just don't see him leaving," Sonny Vaccaro, theNikeexecutive, said last weekend in Seattle. "He's got it made in Vegas. Why would he want to leave?"What if the NCAA assesses a lengthy penalty based on various allegations involving Lloyd Daniels and others?"I . . . still don't see him leaving," persisted Vaccaro.Yet the speculation continues. Within the past few months, he has been rumored reuniting with former Long Beach State athletics director Fred Miller at San Diego State, although that possibility appears moot now that head coach Jim Brandenburg signed a one-year contract extension. Tarkanian's name also has been linked to a pair of the NBA's troubled franchises, the Denver Nuggets and Los Angeles Clippers.One current NBA head coach - another friend of Tarkanian's - says that coaching in the NBA "would kill Tark. He could never accept all the losses." Atlanta Hawks general manager Pete Babcock notes that "coaches who have been very successful, and used to winning 90 percent of games, come into the league and you don't win 90 percent of your games. All of the ex-college coaches I've talked to acknowledge how shocked they are at how different and how demanding the game is."As for Tarkanian, "He's definitely capable," continued Babcock. "He's an outstanding coach. If you look at his team, his team concept of defense is so impressive. He does a terrific job. But typically, a new NBA head coach goes to a struggling team. Would he want that?"; Runnin' Rebels triviaThe Runnin' Rebels' unblemished 27-0 regular-season record was the first in Division I since Alcorn State and Indiana State in 1979. Larry Bird's Indiana State team went 33-1, the sole defeat was against Magic Johnson's Michigan State club in the NCAA title game. The rest, as they say, is history.- According to the 1990-91 media guide, reserve forward Chris Jeter of Morse High in San Diego was recruited by Georgia and lists his favorite player as the Atlanta Hawks' Cliff Levingston, who was his "Big Brother" during his childhood. Someone forgot to mention that Levingston changed teams in the offseason.- Seldom-used guard David Rice made the only start of his career Feb. 23 against UC Irvine - on the annual Seniors Night. While the NBA will not come calling, law schools will. Rice was a Rhodes Scholar finalist with a 3.96 grade point average in business and political science.- Besides improving his overall shooting percentage from .553 to .594 this season, Stacey Augmon bettered his 3-point accuracy from .320 to .458, further enhancing his prospects as an NBA lottery pick.- Coach Jerry Tarkanian says that reserve center Elmore Spencer of Atlanta, a former Georgia Bulldog, has always excelled in practice, but struggled in games. "Poor Elmore," said Tarkanian. "One of these games he's going to play well, though." He did, being named Player of the Game against Utah.- UNLV was limited to single-digits in offensive rebounding only three times this season, but twice against schools from New Jersey. The Rebels claimed a season-low four offensive rebounds against Princeton and nine against Rutgers. They also were held to five against New Mexico State.
