Email_Body: Teen-age girls danced and squealed as the rap group 3 Brothers Of Knowledge performed on a gym floor Friday afternoon.     Except for the abundance of fuzzy red-and-white Santa hats, it was hard to tell this was the day before the holiday break at Booker T. Washington Junior High School near Ybor City.     The seventh-graders at the junior high were treated to a day of rap music and Japanese Taiko drumming.      "I thought it was going to be stupid," said Remecia Hardy, 13, of Tampa. "But it's neat. I'm glad I came to school."     The rap group, known as 3 B.O.K., encouraged the teens in their rap songs to come to school and stay away from drugs. They also tried to remind the pupils that although some of them were looking forward to Christmas mornings full of gifts such as Nintendos andNikeshoes, there were others who wouldn't be so lucky.     "It's Christmas, and you probably aren't thinking about the homeless," said group leader Greg Hunt, 21, of St. Petersburg, during a lull in the performance. "But there are people who are starving throughout the year, and you need to remember them."     While the pupils enjoyed the rap act, they weren't so sure about the Japanese Taiko Drummers, also from St. Petersburg. But they managed to keep the squirming and whispering to a minimum while Lorraine and Asoka Compton pounded on the giant drums.     "For this age group, sitting still and listening to music that's not from their world, they did real well," said substitute teacher Linda Chappell. "They seemed pretty enthralled by it."     Many pupils didn't come to school Friday. Instead, they started their holiday vacation a little early.     "I wasn't going to come. I was going to go to the mall," said Dante Lamar, 13, of Tampa. "But my mom wouldn't let me stay home."     Those who came to school had similar plans of how to spend their time off: avoid studying (many left their books in their lockers) and sleep in.     "Way in," said Jackie Johnson, 12, from Valrico.     Christmas wishes were tempered by economic reality, and most of the pupils acknowledged that they weren't asking their parents for as many things this Christmas.     "My mom is a kindergarten teacher, and she's working all by herself," said Chris Girard, 13, from Brandon. Although his classmates were cheering and screaming to the rap in the gymnasium, Girard was near tears.     "We're really limited this year," he said. His father died in December last year, leaving his mother to care for him and his younger sister. "We can't do as much as we want to do. My grandparents are helping out. We're not getting as much for Christmas. It's real hard, especially around the holidays."

Email_Body: BY GERALD FITZPATRICKSpecial to The Globe and MailMODERN Athens is noisy and polluted, its taxi drivers will often take youonly where they want to go, but it has an incomparable jewel at its heart.Floating serenely above the concrete confusion is the rock of theAcropolis. On its flattened top, the most glorious ruins of antiquity lookdown from another age and at its pinnacle stands the Parthenon, oftencalled the most perfect building in the world and the enduring symbol ofGreece.Inhabited since Neolithic times, the Acropolis has been battered andfought over constantly. After it was devastated by the Persians in 480 BC,the statesman-general Pericles began to rebuild the Acropolis on amonumental scale. In this brief "Golden Age," the Parthenon was completedin 438 BC, followed by the Propylaia, the Temple of AthenaNikeand theErechtheion. For centuries, the city was occupied by a succession of conquerors whoeach added buildings and defences to the site. In 1687, during a longperiod of Turkish rule, the Acropolis was attacked by Venetian forces. Anexplosion rocked the Parthenon, which the Turks were using as a powdermagazine. Fourteen columns were blown apart cutting the temple in two.Fire raged for two days and the Turks surrendered the site for severalmonths.In 1833 the Turks were finally defeated and the modern Greek state wasborn. The new monarch, King Otho, wanted to build a new palace on theAcropolis, but fortunately his plans were rejected as too costly. Worksoon began to remove the clutter of buildings that had been added to theAcropolis since classical times, and restoration has gone on almostcontinuously ever since. During the past 50 years, however, deteriorationof the site from erosion has increased at an alarming rate. Ironreinforcing rods used in earlier restoration work caused serious marbledamage, but the effects of sulphurous pollution have been even worse. Ironreinforcement is now being replaced by titanium, and copies of survivingsculptures have been substituted for the originals.We stayed at the Hotel Phillipos, in the shadow of the Acropolis, onthree occasions between visits to other parts of mainland Greece and theislands. Each time we returned we were given a room on a higher floor.During our last visit, we had a room with its own roof terrace that lookedstraight up at the south side of the Parthenon: we saw the ancient templeglow in the morning sun, glisten at midday and turn pink in the sunset. Wesaw it by moonlight and floodlight. It was a view of which we never tired.On our first morning, we climbed the worn marble steps leading to theceremonial entrance of the Beule Gate. Beyond it was the Propylaia, amonumental gateway originally planned to extend across the entire width ofthe Acropolis. It was to be exactly as wide as the Parthenon was long, butwork stopped when the Peloponnesian War broke out and the building wasnever finished. The Propylaia remained almost intact until the 13thcentury when it was used as a Byzantine palace. It was severely damaged bylightning when it too was used as a Turkish powder magazine in the 17thcentury.Perched dramatically on a platform next to the south wing of thePropylaia is the little Temple of AthenaNike, one of the gems of theAcropolis, with an Ionic portico of slim fluted columns at either end.Built to celebrate the peace with Persia, it was destroyed by the Turks,reconstructed in the 1830s but dismantled and rebuilt again in the 1930swhen its foundation became insecure.We walked through the Propylaia, and before us, at the highest point ofthe Acropolis, stood the Parthenon. Built to honour the goddess AthenaPolias, it has 17 columns on each side and eight at either end, each morethan two metres wide at their base and 10 metres high.The precise mathematical skill that went into the design of theParthenon is astonishing. It is said that there is not a single straightline in the entire building: horizontal lines that seem straight and trueactually rise in the centre, while columns bulge half way up and thentaper toward the top. Pericles ensured that the finest sculptors in Athensworked on the decorative friezes surrounding the temple. He succeeded sowell that the Parthenon came to be looked upon by Athenians as an artisticmasterpiece rather than as a holy place.Until the Venetian offensive, the temple survived more or less intactfor about 2,000 years, serving in its time as a Christian church and aMuslim mosque - complete with a minaret. Sadly, the most serious damagecame from the ravages of 18th century antiquarians who began to removeparts of the Parthenon's decorative friezes. The most flagrant example ofthis, which still angers the Greek people, was by Lord Elgin, the Britishambassador to Turkey. In 1801, he was given permission to remove a largepart of the frieze and other figures, which are now in the British Museumin London.North of the Parthenon is the Erechtheion, the last temple built on theAcropolis, its fine detail acting as a delicate foil to the massiveParthenon. The Erechtheion's crowning feature is the south porch where thesupporting columns are in the form of six maidens, called "caryatids"after the women of Karyai on the Peloponnese peninsula. During the Turkishoccupation, the military governor housed his harem in the Erechtheion andthe caryatids were said to have blushed with shame. In the 19th century,moulds were taken of the original caryatids, which have now been replacedwith copies in order to prevent further deterioration.As we travelled around Athens, I kept looking for glimpses of theParthenon through the forest of television antennas bristling above theconcrete buildings. On our last day in the city, I went back to theAcropolis for a final visit. It seemed to draw me like a magnet. In spiteof the blinding sun and the crowds, I wanted to etch those images on mymind once more. As I left through the Propylaea, I turned and took onelast lingering look. There the Parthenon sat, battered and worn after2,400 years. I tried to imagine people staring up at this same timelessbuilding more than a thousand years ago. Called "the emblem ofcivilization" and "the victory of order over chaos," the victory of theAcropolis' crowning gem seemed even more supreme as I took a deep breathand descended into the modern city.

Email_Body: The EconomistWHEN, late last year, PepsiCo Inc. unveiled a new television commercialin the United States sneering at the products of its perennial rival,Coca-Cola Co., not an eyebrow was raised.By the rough and tumble standards of U.S. advertising, where corporatebosses inveigh against foreign competitors and food companies have beenknown to accuse one another of causing cancer, the Pepsi ad seemed gentle.In it, a sip of Coke turns M. C. Hammer, a rap-music star who normallysounds as if he has several bits of gravel lodged in his throat, into asyrupy crooner. A swig of Pepsi, naturally, returns him to form.Tame stuff - or so it seemed until the commercial was broadcast inJapan. There it has sparked a furious legal row between the two companies,forcing the ad off the air after complaints to Japan's Fair TradeCommission. Although comparative advertising has been legal in Japan since 1987, itis frowned upon. But some Japanese ad people say that if the tradecommission rules in Pepsi's favour, it may become more acceptable. Inparts of Europe, where the tactic is known as "knocking copy," it alreadyhas.As comparative advertising grows ever more popular - and pointed - inthe United States, governments around the world are under pressure toliberalize their rules.That pressure is coming directly from most ad agencies and some oftheir clients. Increasingly they see comparative advertising as aneffective way for new brands - especially fast-moving consumer goods - tobreak into markets, or for established but tired ones to regain lostmarket share.To bolster their case, they cite famous American success stories suchas Federal Express Corp., the overnight mail courier that establisheditself by knocking the leisurely U.S. Postal Service.But regulators remain wary. Free-market arguments supporting the freeflow of consumer information and lower barriers to market entry must bebalanced, they say, against the dangers of deceptive or slanderous ads andagainst "intellectual property" claims by companies over their brandedimages. In fact, comparative ads are not, in most cases, pernicious; butneither are they usually very effective.The folly of the regulators can be seen most plainly in Europe.Yesterday, the European Commission approved a proposal ostensiblypermitting comparative advertising in the European Community from 1993.But there is a catch, or rather, seven of them. All are limits that anyadvertiser would need to observe when knocking another brand.Taken together, the restrictions in effect ban all but the narrowest -and most commercially fruitless - comparative ads. Pepsi's M. C. Hammercommercial would be doomed in the EC unless the company could producescientific evidence of Coke's effect on Mr. Hammer's vocal chords.So would other image-based ads now in vogue in the United States, suchas those in the entertaining war being waged againstNikeInc.'s Air brandof athletic shoes by virtually all of its competitors. LA Gear Inc. chides"Everything else is just hot air;" British Knights, another competitor, isless artful: "Your mother wearsNike."Comparative advertising has been common in the United States since themid-1960s. In that time, it has produced some of the country's mostbrilliant commercials - the Pepsi ad in which young people in the distantfuture find a relic (a Coke bottle) so ancient they cannot identify it;the famous ad for Wendy's, a fast-food restaurant, which jibed McDonald'shamburgers by asking "Where's the beef?"What comparative advertising has not done is show that it helps to sellproducts. Pepsi still lags far behind Coke; Wendy's does not have half ofMcDonald's market share.There are exceptions. According to research by Leo Burnett, a Chicago-based agency, a clever, well-executed comparative ad can be particularlyhelpful in two circumstances.The first is establishing a new brand against entrenched rivals:General Mills Inc. successfully launched its breakfast cereal Total bysaying it was the same as Kellogg Co.'s Corn Flakes but with morevitamins.The second is in a tightly contested market with lots of brands, wheretiny short-term gains are needed to stay profitable. There are more than200 brands in the $900-million U.S. breakfast-cereal market; only 31 ofthem have more than 1 per cent of it. Hence the use of comparative ads byvirtually all of them.But on the whole, says Chris Macrae, a brands consultant at CoopersLybrand Deloitte, comparative advertising makes little sense for anestablished brand. "The brands that last are those that define themselvespositively, not in opposition to someone else," he argues. Market leadersoften gain nothing by giving their rivals free exposure, while brands thatknock market leaders tacitly admit they are not No. 1.Worse, an extended slugging match can simply subtract value from thewhole market. When Bristol-Myers Squibb Co. introduced Datril, a headachedrug that it advertised as identical to Tylenol only cheaper, Tylenolreduced its prices, dooming Datril's campaign but reducing its ownrevenues as well.Two years of back and forth in the United States between soybean andpalm oil producers about the deleterious effects on health of each other'sproducts did nothing but stop many people from buying all edible oils.

Email_Body: BY JOANNE LIPMANWALL STREET JOURNALIF you think television commercials aren't as good as they used to be,you may be right. New U.S. research suggests that they are becoming lessmemorable, even as print advertising is holding relatively steady.A study by Video Storyboard Tests Inc., which tracks advertisingpopularity among consumers, found that the percentage of people who canname an outstanding TV campaign has plummeted over the past five years. In1986, 64 per cent of the people polled could, unaided, cite favouritecampaigns - a figure that plunged to just 48 per cent by last year. At thesame time, print advertising's memorability has hovered in the range of 26to 31 per cent. Not surprisingly, the most memorable print campaigns are the ones thathave lasted the longest and spent the most money on splashy multiple-pagespreads. Among them:Nike, Calvin Klein, Camel, Revlon and Absolut.Advertisers have written off print, but the numbers clearly show thatdollar for dollar, it is becoming a better value than TV advertising, saysDavid Vadehra, Video Storyboard's president. And it's becoming betterevery day: TV advertising's cost increases continue to far outpace thoseof print, despite TV's dwindling memorability, data from ad agency McCann-Erickson show.Ad executives say TV advertising in the United States is suffering asviewers zap ads, turn to video cassettes and are just plain overwhelmed bythe clutter of commercials on network, local and cable stations. At thesame time, TV ads are more frequently substituting glitz and fancyphotography for good ideas, they say.It's hard "to find a really badly executed piece of TV advertising anymore, but it's very easy to find a lot of irrelevant, rotten ideas," saysMartin Purls, chief executive officer and president of ad agency Ammirati& Purls, which created the Ultimate Driving Machine campaign for BMW.Print advertising, meanwhile, particularly in magazines, is gettingmore sophisticated as marketers learn to make better use of the lessexpensive medium. The most important lesson they've learned: consistency.A look at Video Storyboard's top 10 U.S. print campaigns for 1990 showsthat most are at least three years old and several have been running formore than a decade. There isn't a limited-run campaign in sight.Marlboro cigarettes, for one, has been a top-10 staple in the UnitedStates for years, thanks to the Marlboro Man cowboy: he was introduced byad agency Leo Burnett back in 1954. And Absolut vodka's award-winningcampaign took a full decade to make the grade. It made its debut in thetop-10 list at No. 5 this year, although the distinctive campaign usingartists' renditions of Absolut bottles and puns like "Absolut perfection"has been running since 1981. Guess jeans' black-and-white photographs ofsex kittens, and Camel's cartoon mascot, the butt-puffing Joe Camel, havealso become fixtures in magazines.Consistency and continuity - that's the "secret for magazines if youwant to be visible," says Dick Costello, president and chief operatingofficer of Absolut's ad agency, TBWA. "For us, that's the way to useprint. It's a slow-building medium." Video Storyboard's Mr. Vadehrabelieves that "in print, consistency is even more important than in TV."Making a big impression in print, while often cheaper than TV, stillisn't for those with small pocketbooks. Most of the top-10 print campaignsused costly multipage ads, includingNike, Calvin Klein and Guess jeans.Special effects, such as the puzzle stamp and musical ads Absolut has run,can cost even more than TV advertising.Spending a lot of money in itself, though, is no guarantee that a printcampaign will break through. While the big auto makers are all major printadvertisers, only two of them, Infiniti at No. 6 and Ford at No. 9, madethe top 10. Infiniti stood out because of its controversial campaign usingzen-inspired nature scenes to introduce the car, Mr. Vadehra says. Fordmade the cut, he says, because its ads, unlike those of its competitors,use the same distinctive layout and logo to tout all its product lines.Print remains a tough sell, though. For clients and ad agencyexecutives alike, the glitz of TV is too alluring to ignore. Printadvertising, solid but so often unexciting, runs a distant second choice.Advertisers often "feel the 'second team' (at an ad agency) works on printads. When I was on the agency side, everyone wanted to work on TV," saysBill Landgraf, director of media planning for Kraft General Foods, one ofthe largest advertisers in the United States.Ammirati & Purls's Mr. Purls sees that phenomenon daily. Last year, heconsidered hiring a senior creative executive at a salary of more than$200,000. Then he asked to see the man's print work. "He doesn't doprint," came the reply. "There's an attitude," Mr. Purls says. He didn'thire the executive, and he says that the attitude problem helps explainwhy the quality of some print advertising "is appalling. It's basic humannature and greed. They want to do TV."Magazines and newspapers are trying desperately to prove that print adscan be as effective as TV commercials, or even more so. Family Circle, apublication of the New York Times Co. Magazine Group, recently completed astudy of nearly 100,000 households in which it tracked purchases of 22brands advertised in the magazine over 28 weeks. It found that householdsbuying the magazine spent 7 per cent more a week on groceries than acontrol group and that sales of products advertised in the magazineincreased for 15 of the 22 brands."Print advertising can be a highly effective means of increasingproduct sales," concludes Rebecca McPheters, a magazine group vice-president.Translating that into an increase in print advertising, though,promises to be tricky. "We certainly need to look at more than just TValone," Kraft General Foods' Mr. Landgraf concedes. But, he adds,"publishers have long felt the creative product going into magazineswasn't as high a standard as television - and I think their estimationsare correct."

Email_Body: BY JOHN BARBERSpecial to The Globe and Mail"BOY, am I on a roll," exclaimed graphic designer Rick Valicenti, pausingin mid-tangent to comment on the weird and unexpected directions hisMonday evening lecture at Harbourfront was taking. "And," he added, "Ihave no way of knowing where I'm going."Mr. Valicenti, a speaker in Virtu's Centrifuge lecture series, had noidea where he was going because he had mounted the podium armed withlittle more than a collection of recent newspaper clippings and a promiseto "try to catch a stream of consciousness." The stream he caught took himfrom the Buddha's sayings to the mystery of flea-market toothpick holders,from the winemaking skills of Francis Ford Coppola to the motives ofneighbours bearing casseroles. "If you want me to speak specifically aboutgraphic design," he said, "we can do that later." Mr. Valicenti's audience of young graphic designers wasn't in the leastdisappointed with the impish designer's "Zen Rick" shtick, however. He isa hero who could have lectured in Esperanto to a rapt audience. That isbecause at 39, Mr. Valicenti has accomplished something every one of themyearns to do: he has risen to the very top of his profession without theslightest compromise to his own highly original and personal style ofdesign.As the creative force behind the Chicago studio Thirst, Mr. Valicenticame to Toronto billed as one of America's "cutting edge" graphicdesigners. Certainly the slides he used to accompany his lecture, alongwith a recently self-published booklet of his work, substantiated thatclaim. Here there is little distinction between graphic and fine art: aportrait of rap star Vanilla Ice as a pimple-faced, dragon-tongued culturethief, several Cubist meditations on a gum wrapper, a dictionary shreddedmessily by a chainsaw.Sometimes Mr. Valicenti's images are accompanied by a jokey textwritten in the idiom of a vanity licence plate. Thus his studio, Thirst,becomes 3st; his booklet is THISRT and his motto, BEZ. His quirky use oftype combines a modernist's fascination with type's abstract shapes and achild's lofty indifference to all established conventions regarding itsuse.What Mr. Valicenti didn't show was much of his commercial work, whichon the evidence he provided is only slightly more conventional. Many ofhis clients (including Gilbert Paper, the contract furniture companySteelcase and Cooper Lighting) direct their advertising to designers andare therefore more willing to take risks. "Their threshhold for pain ismuch higher than everyone else's," Mr. Valicenti jokes.But how can a man who was recently contracted by a Japanese candycompany to design a Valentine's Day series of chocolates - called RickValicenti's Gentle Manhattan Love - fail to become a star? Especially whenone of the bonbons is a pink-coloured chocolate screw with a heart-shapedhead?Many of the images Mr. Valicenti did choose, which included everythingfrom Soviet Constructivist El Lissitzky's business card to a detail fromMichelangelo's Pieta, revolved in a cryptic, Zen-like way around the issueof integrity. "It's very easy to forget why you participate in aprofession," he told a questioner, "because as soon as you areparticipating you encounter people who want to beat you up." Resistingthem is only half the battle. The goal, says Mr. Valicenti, is to"transcend our real purpose, satisfy all our constraints and delight atthe same time."There's so much stuff that abuses humans in the name of greed, and weas graphic designers wrestle with that all the time. Are we mercenaries?Odds are we are. But on some level we have to draw the line and say, 'Hey,we can still sell your product to all those people who are 25 to 35 yearsold and white and go shopping with a grocery cart - we can still sell moreof it than the competition - but in doing that maybe we can also help bygiving them something of real value."It beats just making "more fodder for the landfill." But it's still alimited ambition, and for the time being it plays to a limited audience.Mr. Valicenti knew he ran the risk of losing his audience when he foundedThirst in 1988, after working on a catalogue for French designer PhilippeStarck, and committed himself wholly to his own vision. In fact, most ofthe clients who loved the work of R. Valicenti Design couldn't stomachThirst. But the designer had started on the path that quickly carried himto the top echelon of his profession.Now, he dreams of carrying his uncompromised personal vision to themass market. "I'm so anxious now for an opportunity to do something thathas a large audience," he says. For months, he daydreamed about doing atelevision campaign forNike. Then, last Thursday,Nikecalled and askedto see his portfolio. His delight in the call is mixed with dread. "I havea feeling there's going to be so many account executives preceding everypresentation that my involvement with the client is just going to get lostin space," he says. "But I hope I can extend my esthetic to speak to ahuge audience, and I hope it will have the same kind of integrity behindit." One thing is for sure: transposing the graphic insights of Zen Rickto the mass market won't BEZ.John Barber is a Toronto-based freelance writer.

Email_Body: BY LESLIE C. SMITHLAST weekend, I asked my nephew, who is turning five, what he wanted forhis birthday. In an excited tone, Owen replied: "You know what Daddy'sgetting me? Basketball shoes!"It seems to start young, this predilection for athletic footwear. I canremember myself, close to Owen's age, watching with mouth agape anAmerican television ad for Keds sneakers. A group of bad guys was chasinga kid who, thanks to his rubber-soled Keds, leapt right over an eight-footchain-link fence and escaped.Gosh, I wanted those shoes. I believed in them, the same way I believedthat drinking whole milk and eating Wonder Bread would endow me withbulging biceps. When at last I got my own pair of Keds, I tried my best toleap over tall fences, but the magic was not there. I was left with vaguefeelings of inadequacy: Was I to blame, or was it the shoes? Today's running shoes - and the TV ads for them - are moresophisticated. Sports superstars, famous directors and multi-million-dollar specialty stores have turned the simple sneaker into an air-padded,lug-soled, Zorbathane-inserted, high-priced must-have for kids and adultsalike.Yet the message is the same. With a pair of high-topNikeAir Force180s strapped to your feet, you too can play basketball like MichaelJordan. If you can't, it's not the shoes' fault.So what if you don't even play basketball? The point is, these shoesare cool. Boy or man, you can flash the design logo and impress yourfriends. Forget the questions: Will these shoes be good for walking aroundin? Or will they end up damaging my arches? Questions are for sissies. Asthe ads say, Just Do It. Spend the $180 plus taxes. Buy yourself or yourchild a not-so-cheap thrill.You realize that just doing it in Detroit could cost you your life. Inmany American inner-cities, a good pair ofNikesis worth their weight inRolex watches. You might as well hang a sign around your neck that saysMug Me.You have to be careful, too, how you do up your shoelaces. In theUnited States, the way they're tied can indicate gang affiliation. Thecoolest of the cool often leave their laces completely undone, a stylederived from prison life where shoelaces are routinely removed to preventsuicide attempts. A neatly tied shoe, in contrast, is a sure sign ofnerdiness whether south of the border or in more moderate Canada.There are people who actually buy athletic shoes for use in sports.Spending over a hundred bucks for a pair might, to them, seem well worththe money. But as anyone who has recently visited a footwear store willtestify, buying only one pair of athletic shoes is not easy.You may solve some of your selection problems by purchasing cross-trainers, but chances are you won't find a pair that cover all yoursporting activities. What if you like tennis with a little weight-trainingon the side? Then you'll need two different pairs of shoes. For biking orhiking on weekends, another couple of pairs.The jogging shoe is a separate entity, as is the aerobics shoe. Andjust when you thought it was safe to go to the gym, along comes Reebokwith its brand new Step Aerobics shoe. That's right, a training shoe foruse solely in stepping up and down on a stair riser.I imagine that sooner rather than later, people will get fed up withthe surfeit of athletic shoes on the market. Already, the style punditsare predicting a return to the simple, blue-and-white striped AdidasGazelles that were so popular during the seventies. Me, I'm holding outfor the original Keds runner. Some dreams never die.

Email_Body: Admission to advertising's biggest, and diciest, extravaganza, the Super Bowl, may have tripled in the past decade - from $ 275,000 to $ 800,000 for 30 seconds' worth of 100 million Americans' attention - but sponsors are still rushing to the game, checkbooks in hand."We're actually in pretty good shape," says Jake Keever, by way of understatement. Mr. Keever is executive vice president of sales at ABC, which is broadcasting the game Jan. 27. "We have two spots unsold on the game, and four people are chasing them."ABC will fetch $ 45 million from the 56 30-second spots during the game, and another $ 9 million from the 2 1/2 hours of pregame and postgame shows, which the network is selling for prices ranging from $ 110,000 to $ 450,000 for 30 seconds. All but four of these spots are sold. The game was such a blowout last year (the San Francisco 49ers drubbed the Denver Broncos 55-10), viewers tuned out the second half and the game received the lowest rating in two decades. That's had a chilling effect."Our clients are going into the NFL playoffs, it's safer," says Larry Kapold, an executive vice president with Foote Cone & Belding, whose clients include previous Super Bowl advertisers Mazda Motors of America and Levi Strauss & Co.But for many advertisers - such as Coca-Cola and Pepsi-Cola - a chance to skewer a competitor or introduce a new product in front of the year's largest TV audience is a chance they can't afford to miss.Among this year's biggest Bowlers:Coca-Cola and Walt Disney World. They're co-sponsoring a 12-minute halftime show featuring New Kids on the Block. At the beginning of half, Atlanta-based Coca-Cola will air a special "Crack the Code for Real Refreshment" ad, enabling game-card holders (the company hopes to distribute 75 million cards before the game) to hold their cards up to the screen and become instant winners. The commercial emits a special signal that "decodes" the cards. Prizes range from coupons for Diet Coke to a single cash prize of $ 1 million.Pepsi-Cola, not to be outdone, says it will make millionaires of three viewers on game day through its Diet Pepsi "You've Got the Right One Baby, Uh-Huh!" call-in promotion. Viewers get game instructions in commercials aired before and during the game, then call a toll-free number. A recorded message by singer Ray Charles, who appears in the commercials, asks callers to sing the new Diet Pepsi theme song, and leave their name and address. Finalists will be chosen randomly, and the three $ 1 million winners will be announced in a post-game commercial.Athletic shoe rivalsNikeand L.A. Gear will go toe to toe. L.A. Gear hired the same creative team - now at a different agency - that created the famous "1984" Super Bowl spot for Apple Macintosh computers to create an ad to launch its new Catapult shoe. And the agency that created the "Bo Knows"Nikeads is producing the kickoff campaign for the NikeAir 180.Anheuser-Busch is taking its Bud Bowl into the third year, spending $ 6 million to air its farcical football games between bottles of beer.Panasonic is spending $ 4 million on six commercials to promote its corporate image and new products.Other advertisers slated to appear on the game include McDonald's, AT&T, Federal Express, United Parcel Service, and Master Lock Co.; Safe harbor?Real estate is hardly recession-proof. The Fed's $ 2.3 billion bailout of The Bank of New England this week (largely because of bad real estate loans) is evidence enough of that.Still, in the throes of a recession, Atlanta's Austin Kelley Advertising this week began a print campaign in Florida newsppaers promoting Arvida Communities in Florida as a safe investment in a recession.One ad urges investors who are "looking for signs of stability in the economy" to look no further than Arvida. Another reads, "When the future looks a little uncertain, it's time to review the lessons of the past." The ads explain that Arvida properties have "weathered economic storms for 30 years . . . and have remained both a solid value and South Florida's most beautiful way of life."Compiled from staff, wire and published reports.

Email_Body: Documents revealing how much Vince Dooley made as football coach and athletics director at Georgia in 1986 reveal how a coach's outside income can dwarf his salary.Of the $ 374,497.89 Dooley received that year, only $ 125,500 came from Georgia. The remaining $ 248,997.89 came from a shoe company, radio and television contracts, speaking engagements, and a football camp. Repeated attempts to contact Dooley by telephone were unsuccessful.According to documents obtained by The Journal-Constitution under an order by the Georgia Supreme Court, Dooley's salary for the year was $ 95,000. In addition, he received $ 4,500 in expenses, plus a $ 26,000 premium paid on an annuity.He also had use of a luxury automobile and housing. The house in which Dooley resides was deeded to him by Georgia's athletics association several years ago.The documents show that Dooley received $ 152,341.77 for his weekly television shows during the 1986 football season, plus another $ 30,000 for appearing on Georgia's football radio network shows, another $ 9,000 for 11 tailgate shows and $ 6,000 for a weekly call-in show on WGST-AM.Additionally, the documents show Dooley received $ 30,000 from aNike shoe contract (not including $ 2,000 worth of merchandise, 300 pairs of shoes for his team, plus another 100 because the Bulldogs went to a bowl game, and $ 500 in merchandise for each of 12 assistants).Dooley resigned as head coach effective at the conclusion of Georgia's Gator Bowl victory over Michigan State on Jan. 1, 1989, but remains athletics director.The documents on Dooley's income originally were requested by The Journal-Constitution in 1987 under the state open records act. University president Charles Knapp agreed to release them, but Dooley, men's basketball coach Hugh Durham and women's basketball coach Andy Landers filed suit in Fulton County Superior Court in December 1987 to prevent release of the records.The Georgia Supreme Court ruled Nov. 29 last year that all but two of the documents in question were public domain.Another hearing is scheduled for Fulton County Superior Court Jan. 28 before Judge Frank Hull in which requests for other Georgia documents plus similar files detailing athletic-related outside income of Georgia Tech coaches will be argued.
email_title: Reebok battles to regain top in image contest withNike

Email_Body: Vince Dooley says his athletically related income - documented earlier this week at more than $ 374,000 in 1986 - explains why his wife didn't want him to quit coaching."That's exactly the reason Barbara didn't want me to give up coaching after 25 years," Dooley said. "When we got to Georgia, my salary was $ 12,500. I got a $ 2,000 subsistence allowance and a $ 1,000 television package - $ 100 per game - for a grand total of $ 15,500. That's probably about what I was worth then. "I finally reached a respectable salary in light of the job I was doing," Dooley said, "and Barbara didn't want me to give up the greatest portion of it."Dooley retired as head coach after the 1988 season, but stayed on as athletics director.Documents made public by order of the Georgia Supreme Court indicate Dooley made $ 197,342 from radio and TV shows in 1986, $ 30,000 from a shoe contract withNike,$ 5,250 from his summer football camp and $ 2,406 for a cap endorsement - a total of $ 234,998, which he no longer receives.ROCKET MAN: Notre Dame football player Raghib "Rocket" Ismail, who announced Thursday he will forgo his senior season in favor of the NFL, will be transformed into a corporation - "Team Rocket" - that is expected to convert his clean image into millions of dollars. Ismail already has assembled a team of negotiators, financial advisors and attorneys. It's been estimated he could gross $ 25 million almost immediately upon signing a pro football contract.GOING, GOING, GONE: The Atlanta Braves' "Smiling Indian" logo is quietly being phased out as an official symbol of the team. According to Steve Goff, merchandise manager of the Braves Clubhouse at CNN Center, the team will emphasize the tomahawk with either "Atlanta" or "Braves" written above it. However, in order to protect the trademark - and to satisfy some customers who specifically ask for the smiling Indian emblem on their merchandise - the Braves' catalog this year will feature one or two items with that logo.GUESTS OF HONOR: University of Georgia ticket manager Freddy Jones says the expansion of Sanford Stadium, raising capacity from 82,122 to 86,357, will mean more end-zone seating for visiting fans and more sideline seating for Bulldogs fans. Construction in the lower level of the west end zone is under way and will be complete in time for the 1991 season. Georgia has sold all of its 48,000 season tickets every year since 1980, but Jones doesn't expect to sell out this season - even with a home schedule that includes games against LSU, Clemson, Auburn and Kentucky - because of the addition of 4,235 extra seats.RINGER: A Georgia Tech players committee appointed to decide on the design of the Yellow Jackets' football national championship rings heard presentations from three companies this week - Herff Jones, Jostens and Balfour. According to assistant athletics director Jim Murphy, NCAA rules allow schools to purchase championship awards for players as long as the price is under $ 300. . . . Along with hot dogs, popcorn, soft drinks, T- shirts, pom-pons and bumper stickers, Tech students can purchase an MCI long-distance telephone calling card in the concourse of Alexander Memorial Coliseum. Murphy explained MCI's presence was part of a contractual agreement between the company and the athletics association to provide access to students.SEMINOLE PRICE UPRISING: Insisting that Florida State basketball "has been underpriced," Seminoles athletics board member Fred Standley says ticket prices would increase 60 percent - from $ 95 per season ticket to $ 150 - when the school begins ACC competition next season. . . . Tampa will spend approximately $ 2 million on hosting the Super Bowl, but the economic impact to the city will be approximately $ 120 million in direct spending. . . . Taking a hint from the NCAA, Mississippi junior college presidents have decided to cut costs by reducing scholarship limits across the board. The ceiling on football scholarships will drop from 30 to 28 beginning next season.
email_title: Reebok battles to regain top in image contest withNike

Email_Body: Reebok's "Pump Up and Air Out" ad campaign, launched during the Super Bowl and featuring Atlanta Hawks forward Dominique Wilkins, will cost the company $ 20 million during its three-month run - the shoe manufacturer's most expensive promotional blitz ever.Various ads also will feature Dennis Rodman of the Detroit Pistons, Boomer Esiason of the Cincinnati Bengals, golfer Greg Norman, tennis player Michael Chang and decathlete Dave Johnson.Reebok's "Pump" device is now standard equipment in 36 models of shoes, and "Air Out" is a none-too-subtle snipe atNike'sAir Jordan line.And if $ 20 million seems like a lot to spend to promote an inflatable shoe, consider Pump sales already are well over $ 200 million since the shoe was introduced in November 1989. Reebok's total sales for 1989 were more than $ 1.8 billion. INTERFACING: Persons-Majestic Inc. has come up with a new twist on the war in the Middle East: white bicycle seats with Saddam Hussein's face on it. "I think it's pretty clear what we're saying," company president Richard Sanderson told Outside Business magazine. The company is donating 50 cents to the American Red Cross for every seat sold. ... The University of Florida Athletic Association has contributed $ 600,000 to the university's emergency fund, which was established to counter state-mandated budget reductions. Gators football coach Steve Spurrier earmarked $ 50,000 of his own money for women's athletics and the College of Health and Human Performance, from which he graduated. . . . Former major league baseball players Darrel Chaney and Ron Blomberg, both Atlanta-area residents, learned about job relocation the hard way. Chaney was traded five times in an eight-month period, while Blomberg's career was cut short by a series of injuries. Now Chaney is regional director of marketing for Corporate Transfer Service, a relocation company, and Blomberg is senior vice president and a senior partner with USA Career MarNON-SIGNS OF THE TIMES: Drag racer Shirley Muldowney, citing the poor state of the nation's economy, is down to only one sponsor - herself - and wonders if she will make it through the 18-event NHRA season. The one-season price-tag to race: $ 1 million. ... New water fountains in addition to the eight already in place at Legion Field - all located at the south end of the stadium - aren't a part of renovations scheduled to be completed in time for the 1991 football season, forcing thirsty fans to buy soft drinks at $ 1.25 each...The proposed sale of the Montreal Expos for $ 86 million has been delayed because of questions some major league owners have about changes in the diverse financial partnership, which ranges from a credit union to a food company to the city of Montreal. The sale must be approved by 75 percent of National League owners and 50 percent of American League owners. . . . According to the National Sporting Goods Association, the average annual revenue from table time at a pool hall is $ 107,482, and the average cost of a stationary bicycle rose from $ 120.94 in 1985 to $ 192.69 in 1989.BIDDING WAR: Memphis has declared war on Jackson, Miss., by offering $ 1 million to lure the Arkansas-Ole Miss football game from Memorial Stadium to the Liberty Bowl. The game, held in Jackson in odd-numbered years since 1981, has played before shrinking audiences in recent seasons. At $ 20 per ticket this fall, the city would have to sell 50,000 tickets just to break even if it matches the Memphis offer. A crowd of only 42,000 watched the 1989 game in Jackson, which at $ 20 per ticket would have resulted in a $ 160,000 deficit for the city on a $ 1 million guarantee. "We have made no decision yet on the site of the Arkansas game," Ole Miss athletics director Warner Alford said, "but it's purely a budgetary matter with me. I've got to do whatever is in the best interest of the department." ... Wayne McDuffie, the University of Georgia's new offensive coordinator, hasn't signed a contract yet, but once the recruiting season is over he will sign a two-year deal calling for an $ 85,000 salary the first year, $ 90,000 the next, according to athletics di

Email_Body: A burglar broke into a unit at the Asbury Apartments on Jimmy Carter Boulevard Sunday morning and left with more than $ 3,000 in clothes and shoes, a Gwinnett County police report showed.The resident returned to her unit to find the front door standing open and clothes and debris scattered inside, police said.Items stolen included five men's sweaters, five pairs of men's pants, four pairs of shoes, six pairs of jeans, six dresses, three suits, aNikesporting jacket and an AT&T cordless phone. An extensive home entertainment system in the living room was not touched.Police said they have no suspects.TRAFFIC STOP IS A BUST: Lilburn police arrested three people on drug charges during a traffic stop Sunday, jail records showed. All three are being held without bond in the Gwinnett County Jail in Lawrenceville.Arrested were James Leonard Roland, 39, of 4074 Stergan Drive in Buford, charged with two counts of drug possession; Terry Ray Gillespie, 29, of 5320 Sycamore Drive in Lawrenceville, charged with one count of possession of methamphetamine and one count of marijuana possession; and Elise Doreen LaForgia, 41, of 1211 Daniel Lane in Lawrenceville, charged with one count each of violation of the Georgia Controlled Substances Act, DUI, failure to maintain lane and possession of methamphetamine.Police stopped the car because the driver, Ms. LaForgia, was weaving, Sgt. Mike Puglise said. More than 15 grams of methamphetamine, packaged and ready for distribution, were confiscated, he said.Police went to the woman's home, where they found more evidence of methamphetamine distribution, Sergeant Puglise said.ARREST IN ABDUCTION CASE: A Snellville man was arrested Sunday and charged with kidnapping a Jonesboro woman after giving her a ride, jail records show.Tony Clarence Parker, 35, of 3866 Lenora Church Road allegedly beat Jody Marie Kersey with a leather strap and then held her against her will, records show.He also has been charged with aggravated assault, records show.The alleged incident occurred about a month ago, according to GBI Agent Billy Shepherd. The GBI investigated the case at the request of Walton County because the alleged abduction began there, Agent Shepherd said.The suspect was released later Sunday after posting $ 50,100 bail.Staff writer Hollis R. Towns compiled this report.

Email_Body: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla. - The Atlanta Braves rewarded National League rookie of the year David Justice with a $ 195,000 raise Wednesday, signing the outfielder to a one-year contract worth $ 297,000. Justice's deal is the biggest in major-league history for a player entering his second season, according to his agent, Eric Goldschmidt."The most a player had gotten before, going into his second season, was Baltimore pitcher Gregg Olson," said Goldschmidt, a Los Angeles- based agent who also represents Eric Davis and Darryl Strawberry.Olson, who won the American League Rookie of the Year Award in 1989, made $ 270,000 last year.Justice, who made $ 102,000 in 1990, hit .282 with 29 home runs and 81 RBIs. H e blossomed after the trade of Dale Murphy, replacing him in right field and hitting 11 home runs during a 16-game span in August."This just goes along with everything else that is happening in baseball as far as the pay scale," said Braves general manager John Schuerholz. "But I'm not saying David doesn't deserve it, because he had a great season."Justice also has become marketable off the field. His marketing agent, Mike DeSola of PrimeTime Sports Marketing in New York, said Justice has made $ 100,000 from endorsements and autograph shows."He's the hottest sport commodity in Atlanta," said DeSola. "He has a deal withNikeshoes and Easton batting gloves, and by the time he goes to spring training, we will have worked a glove deal with either Rawlings or Regent."With the signing of Justice, the Braves now have 11 players on their 40-man roster not under contract: pitchers John Smoltz, Steve Avery, Tony Castillo, Kent Mercker and Paul Marak; catchers Greg Olson and Kelly Mann; infielders Jeff Blauser, Mark Lemke and Francisco Cabrera, and outfielder/first baseman Tommy Gregg

Email_Body: ANiketennis shoe in the roadway recently was grim evidence of a tragic accident that killed a mother, a Brookwood High School senior and a former student.The teen driving one of the vehicles, a late-model Pontiac Bonneville SSE, was speeding up to 70 mph on a residential street when he lost control and crashed head-on into the woman's van, police said. The mother was heading to Brookwood to pick up her daughter."What caused that wreck is what I refer to as the testosterone level. The driver apparently couldn't resist using the power of his vehicle," George W. Black Jr., Gwinnett's director of transportation, said later. The Feb. 7 crash pushed the number of Brookwood classmates who have died in car wrecks in the last three years to 12.Once again, parents, teens and other members of the community were jolted into re-examining the problem of teen driving habits, something a community task force has been doing since September.The task force, composed of police, legislators, students, parents and teachers at Brookwood, has proposed more than 12 ideas for parents to help make their teens safer drivers.They concluded parents should not help teens buy fast cars, should boost teen awareness of driving safety and should not let teens drive after midnight.While the task force is committed to stemming the tide of teen driving deaths, many students seem fatalistic and unconvinced safety measures can help.When asked what could stop the carnage, one Brookwood junior said too many teens are unsafe drivers but she didn't think anything could be done about it.A senior noted all cars will go 70 mph or 80 mph - more than fast enough to kill someone.Another senior said his driver's education class didn't spend much time on safety.But school officials said safety is definitely a large portion of the course."What a student interprets as not being safety really might be safety," said Dan Chelko, Brookwood's community school director.Do you think it would help if teens were not allowed to drive high- performance cars?; Don't lay the blame on carI don't think you can blame the car unless it's an equipment malfunction. I think the drivers, they err in their judgment, and that's what causes the collision.I haven't seen a car yet that won't go fast enough to kill you. We have teenagers killed in VW Beetles and in Bonnevilles. The car doesn't have a whole lot to do with it. They're going to show off no matter what they are driving. Just like a buck deer when they're in rut, they'll kick up their heels, they'll drop their guard. That's how hunters manage to kill them. Same with a kid. They are not thinking, and that's what kills them.Traffic division supervisor, Gwinnett police; Help teens resist pressureNo. Such a prohibition should be part of a more comprehensive approach that includes helping teens and parents resist the social pressures that cause them to want such cars.Gwinnett school superintendent; Kids shouldn't have carsI don't think they should because they don't use good judgment.If I had a car when I was that age, I might not have been living today. Because I was wild too. And the best way to hold a kid back at that age until they mature more is to not allow them to have those cars, those machines.Former school board member; Driver's safety course firstIf they can afford to pay for them and pay for the insurance and the gas, yes, and after they have taken a driver's safety course.Hopkins Elementary School; Do what some colleges doI don't know. I think one way a solution could be reached would be the same way they do it in college. In the university system, students are not allowed to drive if they are freshmen. I feel like if a high school system would implement that, let them reach their junior and senior years, then they could drive any kind of vehicle as long as they've proved their responsibility.Gwinnett commissioner; Leave it up to teens, parentsI think that should be a parental and teen decision, not a legislative decision.I don't think it would change the accident rate. Responsible driver education and more parental control over the car would reduce the accident rate.I had a Mustang. My parents exercised extreme control. And I had no problem, no tickets, no accidents. Not only should teens be held responsible, parents should be responsible. And if they can't handle it, then teens should not be allowed to have the car.Former president, Gwinnett Association of Educators; These autos made to speedThat was one of the recommendations that we published that we discourage parents from helping young people buy high-performance cars. One of the reasons is there is a tendency with high-performance vehicles to drive fast because that is basically what the cars are made for, high speed. We are concerned in many instances that driver skills do not correspond with the power under the hood, that they can't control it.There is a lot of peer pressure. Parents, in order for their young persons to be popular, will just not use good common sense as far as parenting skills are concerned.Brookwood High School principal; Vehicles don't kill, drivers doI don't have a problem about that. My husband does. We are a very divided household. It was funny you're asking because we were talking about it last night, my son and I on one side and my husband on the other side of the fence. Basically, I feel like the person should have respect for whatever vehicle they're driving, whether it's a bicycle or Trans Am. You have to know your limitations and ability to control that vehicle. I don't see that the vehicle kills; it is the driver.13th District director, Georgia PTA; They are too dangerous'No. I feel they are too dangerous. I feel they are inexperienced to drive something that is high performance. I don't think they are responsible to be under control in all situations.Peachtree Elementary and Norcross High parent; At this age, there's no fearI don't believe that they should be. At this age they have no fear. I just don't think they are mature enough to handle a high-performance car. The reason they have so many of these high-performance cars is peer pressure, and I feel like the parents are responsible for giving in and allowing these children to have these cars.Norcross High School parent; Bad for safety, insuranceI think for their own safety it's not a good idea, especially beginning drivers because they need to get more experience in a less powerful car. I think for economic reasons it wouldn't be a wise decision for a teenager to own one of those cars because of the high insurance.Norcross High School parent

Email_Body: DAYTON, Ohio - Because of unwanted calls, Georgia Tech guard Kenny Anderson has changed his telephone number four times this season. Ohio State's Jim Jackson has gotten it every time.The only time Anderson hopes Jackson won't have his number is today at the University of Dayton Arena, when the Yellow Jackets (17-12) meet the Buckeyes (26-3) in the second round of the NCAA Midwest Regional (Channel 5, 12:20 p.m.). Anderson makes sure Jackson, the Buckeyes' leading scorer, has his phone number because the two are good friends. Still, the Ohio State forward has a score to settle with him dating to their high school days, when Anderson was at Archbishop Molloy in New York and Jackson was at Macomber in Toledo, Ohio.Their paths crossed at a tournament in Myrtle Beach, S.C., during their junior years. Anderson's team won by 20, though neither says he can remember the exact score."We met at aNikeinvitational camp at Princeton and I wanted to meet him because we came out rated the No. 1 and No. 2 players at the camp ," said Jackson, the No. 2. "We found out we were going to play at Myrtle Beach. They beat us by 20, but the friendship continued."It was in full force Saturday, when they twice interrupted interviews with hordes of reporters to trade handshakes and their Dayton hotel phone numbers."We don't get into all that game stuff for Sunday, like I'm going to beat you,' " Anderson said. "Well, during the course of the game, I'll let him know. But I never thought it would come to this. Once I looked at the bracket and saw we were in their regional, I figured we probably will wind up playing each other."Their versions of the last time they met differ slightly. Said Anderson, "He had 40 points and 20 rebounds, I had 40 points and two assists. It was really an exciting game, just battling it out."Said Jackson, "I had 35 points, 20 rebounds and he had like 38. But this game Sunday is a little bit different. More's on the line right now. I want to win. If he scores 50 and we win, that's cool. If he scores 50 and we lose, that's a different story."Tech's second-round game last year featured Anderson against another high-profile Jackson - Chris of LSU. As he did before that game, Anderson is shying away from the hype that today's contest will become a one-on- one affair."It's going to be Georgia Tech vs. Ohio State and I'm going to be ready for the challenge," Anderson said.

Email_Body: R.H. Macy & Co. reported a loss of $ 7.3 million, or $ 9.12 per share, for the second quarter ended Feb. 2 before an extraordinary gain of $ 85.3 million, compared with a loss of $ 39 million, or $ 27.67 a share, for the same period a year ago.The company reported net income of $ 78 million, or $ 43.10 per share, for the second quarter, after the gain, which involved the purchase of debt. Sales for the quarter were $ 2.2 billion, compared with $ 2.44 billion a year ago.For the six-month period, the New York-based retailer - which has 10 stores in metro Atlanta - lost $ 74 million, or $ 53.87 a share, before a $ 95.5 million gain.It lost $ 72.2 million, or $ 51.58 a share, in the same period a year ago. Net income was $ 21.5 million, or $ 4.58 a share, after the gain. Sales for the period were $ 3.74 billion, compared with $ 4.15 billion a year ago.; Other earnings:NikeInc., third quarter: Reported earnings of $ 70.67 million, or 93 cents per share, compared with $ 63.1 million, or 83 cents per share, a year ago.Federal Express, third quarter: Reported a loss of $ 105.64 million, or $ 1.98 per share, compared with earnings of $ 5.21 million, or 10 cents per share, a year ago.; TAKING STOCKL.A. Gear announced a new credit line with its banks Monday, eight weeks after the No. 3 sneaker maker disclosed that a quarterly loss would put it in technical default on its loan agreement.The new agreement will cut L.A. Gear's available credit from $ 360 million to $ 300 million. It is subject to final documentation, which the company said was expected to be completed by the end of March.- From staff and wire reports

Email_Body: His spectacular stardom as a major league outfielder and a National Football League running back defied the sportswriters, the color commentators and other assorted wags who said it couldn't be done. But now the conventional wisdom has apparently caught up with Bo Jackson. In an announcement as sudden and stunning as one of his mammoth home runs or 90-yard touchdowns, the Kansas City Royals baseball team said it was releasing Jackson because of a devastating hip injury he suffered playing football. His career with the NFL's Los Angeles Raiders may also be over.Jackson vows to come back, and perhaps he will be able to do the unexpected again. But the man whose seemingly invincible athletic prowess was summed up by theNikeTV commercial's phrase "Bo knows" now seems destined to be another of those American stars whose careers, like comets, blaze brightly before dying out all too soon.Bo Jackson had a $ 2,375,000 salary with the Royals. Because of his injury, the club is offering him to any team for $ 1. Young hero worshippers dreaming of sports glory should note the difference.

Email_Body: Bo Jackson has moved into the category of damaged goods, and his hip injury could cost the football/baseball all-star $ 100 million or more in long-term salary and endorsement revenue if he is unable to continue his professional career.That's the opinion of Bob Hope, a former Atlanta Braves executive who now is executive vice president of the Burson-Marsteller public relations firm in New York.Jackson's biggest loss of income would be from hisNikeshoe/apparel contract, currently estimated at $ 2.8 million per year. His total endorsement income this year is estimated at $ 4 million.Nikehas said it would not cancel its current contract with Jackson, but the company can drop him when the deal expires after 1993. Because he was waived by the Kansas City Royals, Jackson will draw only one-sixth of his $ 2.375 million salary this year, but he will get his full $ 1.6 million salary from the L.A. Raiders since NFL teams are prohibited from waiving players hurt while playing football.Were Jackson, 28, able to play 10 more seasons, his income likely would have totaled more than $ 100 million, according to Hope.Even if Jackson is able to play baseball later this season, watch forNiketo back off gradually and introduce a replacement, such as former Notre Dame wide receiver Rocket Ismail.MEMPHIS MONEY: Just because Federal Express owner Fred Smith has withdrawn from the ownership picture in the Memphis bid for an NFL franchise doesn't mean the city has abandoned its effort. Smith, alarmed that no one had taken the lead in generating community support necessary for a city to land a franchise, decided to do it himself. That leaves two promising ownership candidates: Billy Donovant, owner of a cotton brokerage firm that does $ 1.2 billion of business annually, and Wall Street commodities broker Paul Tudor Jones, famous for making $ 37 million in one day after the 1989 stock market crash. . . . Preliminary results of an NFL study under way by economists at the University of South Florida indicate that the Super Bowl's economic impact to Tampa was between $ 50 millionand $ 65 million, a long way from the $ 125 million advance estimate. War in the Persian Gulf, economic recession and a one- week period between the conference championships and the Super Bowl were tHEAD OF THE CLASS: As an assignment for a sports administration course he teaches at the University of California, Andy Dolich - executive vice president of the Oakland A's - had six groups of students make presentations on the six cities aspiring for a major league baseball franchise. The class then voted on the city it thought should get the first team. The winner was Miami. . . . Two sellout games between the Yankees and Orioles at Miami's Joe Robbie Stadium on Easter/Passover weekend - one of the toughest draw potentials of the year - show Miami's interest in a baseball franchise. . . . According to U.S. Olympic Committee executive director Harvey Schiller, the 22 companies that have put up nearly $ 22 million to be designated official USOC licensees through 1992 in support of the U.S. teams in Barcelona will generate some $ 400 million in retail sales.

Email_Body: SEATTLE - Because of what he terms "ongoing harassment" by the NCAA, UNLV coach Jerry Tarkanian believes the Runnin' Rebels have become symbols for the working class and the oppressed."I think all the guys that are truck drivers and construction workers all love the Rebels," he said. "Beer drinkers are Rebel fans. If you go in the inner city, I think they're Rebel fans. It just depends. I think probably if you went into Beverly Hills, they're UCLA fans. South Dallas is pulling for the Rebels. So is the inner city of Detroit, Pasadena and the westside of Vegas." JOHNSON MOST OUTSTANDING: UNLV forward Larry Johnson was named Most Outstanding Player of the West regional and was joined on the All- Tournament team by teammates Stacey Augmon and guard Greg Anthony and Seton Hall guard Terry Dehere and Arizona center Brian Williams.WEST VS. WEST: The ongoing feud between Tarkanian and Arizona's Lute Olson, which can be traced back to Olson's recruiting of Tom Tolbert out of Cerritos College, apparently has influenced players on both teams. After the Rebels won the subregional in Tucson, the players left an autographed basketball - "UNLV No. 1" - in the Wildcats locker room. "It took a lot of gall for them to do that," said Arizona forward Brian Williams, adding that the Wildcats brought the ball with them to Seattle for motivation.Well, so much for motivation. The Wildcats were run off by Seton Hall.AROUND THE DOME: Seton Hall coach P.J. Carlesimo is moving slowly these days. He reportedly tore cartilage in his knee while jumping up and down at the Big East tournament and will require arthroscopic surgery . . .Nikeexecutive Sonny Vaccaro - a close friend of both Tarkanian and Carlesimo - refuses to say with whom he's siding. But Vaccaro was less reluctant to take a shot at the NCAA, which, he says, complains about the company's sneaker deals with coaches but has never initiated a conversation. "If it bothers them that all that money goes to coaches, and they're so concerned with academics, why don't they come up with a proposal where 25 percent or so goes directly to tutorial programs for the players?" Vaccaro said.LAZY BOYS? Utah coach Rick Majerus remained in Seattle to watch the UNLV-Seton Hall matchup and enjoy the "big time" for a few days. Among other things, Majerus proclaimed the chairs used for the interview sessions were of higher quality than those at the subregional in Tucson. "We were sitting on folding chairs in Arizona," he said. "What do they get at the Final Four, Lazy Boy recliners?"

Email_Body: The body of an unidentified man, shot twice in the head, was found on a dirt path near 990 Hubbard St. S.W. about 7:30 a.m. Thursday, Atlanta police said. The victim is described as in his late 20s, black, about 5-foot-10 and weighing 165 pounds. Email_Body: Randy Salzman, a former newspaperman, TV producer and college journalism instructor, is a freelance writer living in Augusta."I DON'T THINK FILMMAKERS CAN INFLUENCE or affect anything. . . . Sometimes we can make a ripple, but, I mean, we're just a teaspoon in the ocean."That's a quote from Barry Levinson, the director of "And Justice For All," "Rain Man," and "Good Morning, Vietnam," uttered in the midst of last fall's promotional campaign for his newest film, "Avalon."The quote disturbs. It's a circle-the-wagon response to what should be a wide-open examination of how media affect the real world. It's akin to saying that "Uncle Tom's Cabin" had nothing to do with the Civil War or that William Randolph Hearst's reward of $ 50,000 to anyone proving the Spanish blew up the USS Maine wasn't a cause of the Spanish-American War.Viewers simply cannot help but be "rippled" by the emotional, gut- wrenching influence of huge moving color images backed by Dolby stereo sound.The riots accompanying "New Jack City" this year, or "The Warriors" five years ago, or even John Hinckley's rationale for shooting former President Reagan are the most disturbing examples.; Teaspoons' sell productsThose are, of course, dismissible as the actions of the maladjusted and the mentally ill - not mainstream America. But mainstream America is influenced, as well, by what we see - witness the thousands of young men and women who flocked to Navy recruiting stations after viewing "Top Gun."Film's influence is most easily verified today by the fact that a Hollywood company exists to analyze scripts scene-by-scene to determine where and howNike,Budweiser, Toyota, Pepsi and Kellog's products can best be plugged into feature films.Does Mr. Levinson truly believe these films and the other multinationals purchasing American Film Promotion's services are throwing massive dollars after "teaspoons?"; Images shape opinionsPerhaps the director means that the films we see rarely destroy basic opinions or terminate lifelong value systems. In most cases, that's probably true.But when the attempt is made to alter public opinion, filmmakers can be amazingly effective. If not, why did American audiences find themselves cheering German sailors in the subtitled version of "Das Boot," or the Viet Cong in 1989's "Iron Triangle?"Visual imagery can be brilliantly effective in reinforcing established ideas or in shaping opinions where none exists, often with unintended consequences.Shot after shot of missing children at the close of the television movie "Adam," for example, sent the nation into mass hysteria a few years ago, replete with milk cartons, missing posters, child finger-printings and "don't ever talk to anyone" lectures.Parents all, very rationally, wanted to make certain their children were not among the 50,000 the movie told us disappeared every year.The reactions were logical responses to an intensely emotional film. Even after the news media discovered that 48,500 of those kids were either proven runaways or were taken by the other parent in a divorce, the hysteria continues with milk cartons and ad fliers.; Living on the mean streetsMovies and television programs like this give us what one critic calls the "Mean World Syndrome." We are so sure that everyone out there is trying to rape, kill, hurt, con and rob us that we draw ourselves into individual cocoons, afraid of life. We buy extra locks, bulletproof book bags for our children, alarm systems for our boats, Mace packages for our cars, and guns, guns and more guns.Until the Mean World Syndrome becomes the ultimate - and deadly - Catch 22.Perhaps one or more of the police officers in Los Angeles with the all-too-ready nightsticks have what police call The Wyatt Earp Syndrome - a feeling that the cop's job is to save the world, even if it requires excessive violence.No Los Angeles cop, obviously, has met Wyatt Earp. But they have met his counterpart in countless Friday nights at the theater and Tuesday nights in their living room. People around "Dirty Harry," remember, have a "nasty habit of getting killed."; Power to influence valuesAmerica is just now beginning to grope with the issue of media influence. That's what the boycott of "The Last Temptation of Christ," the trials of 2 Live Crew and Judas Priest, the Parents' Music Resource Center and congressional mandates concerning commercial minutes on children's television are all about. It's why there has been such an uproar over Andrew Dice Clay and Public Enemy, over sex and violence, over blatant commercialism.To state it bluntly: If Hollywood, if the networks, if the record companies won't acknowledge their power to shape values, then Americans are more than willing to take power from them, to alter or bypass the First Amendment.Although the Constitution's decree that Congress shall make no law" sounds absolute, the fact is that Congress, legislatures and the courts have routinely qualified freedom of speech. Examples abound from copyright and libel to recent obscenity rulings.Today, when anti-media public opinion is at a fever pitch, society appears poised to attack again. To prevent it, the film industry and the media in general must quit pretending they create only teaspoons.Each of those teaspoons, society feels, like the 27 men who died playing Russian roulette after viewing "The Deer Hunter," are ripples in a tidal wave.

Email_Body: Many Gwinnett schools have decided not to wait until 1996 for the Olympics. Students are already experiencing the intense competition and international flavor of the Games.Traditional springtime field day activities have been expanded into weeks of researching the customs and culture of foreign countries. Classes then compete as particular nations. "Some of the kids didn't know about other countries until they did this," said Marcia Nolan, a physical education teacher at Lilburn Middle School.The school's Olympic Games included South Korea, Canada, Norway, Mexico and Italy. Students from the sixth through eighth grades were brought together to make up a country. "We tried to pull the school together," Ms. Nolan said.Before the athletic events - such as the 440-yard relay, an obstacle course and a tug of war - the students made their countries' flags and some even painted their faces and arms with the colors of their countries."It really feels like you're in the Olympics," said 12-year-old Nhan Huynh, a Lilburn Middle student."You learn good sportsmanship."While the concept of holding a school Olympics is not new, the fact that the Games will be coming to Atlanta in five years has added fuel to the Olympic fire and given teachers a new method of building student enthusiasm about history, geography, politics and even physical education.Having a schoolwide Olympics is one example of how the county is moving toward an "interdisciplinary curriculum," said Glen Blankenship, social studies coordinator for Gwinnett public schools."Anything we can do that makes students see how subjects are related makes learning that much more real and that much more effective," Dr. Blankenship said, adding that studying the Olympics "gives students a better appreciation for other cultures."Jesse Racine, a seventh-grader at Lilburn Middle School, said he enjoyed learning about his team's country, South Korea."We had to do research on the conflicts and the wars they've had," Jesse said, adding that during the course of his study he also discovered thatNikeshoes and a wide range of electronic devices are made in South Korea. "I think it's a cool country."Junior Spain, a physical education teacher at Dacula Middle School, which held its first Olympics last year, said he felt his school helped bring the 1996 Games to Atlanta."It made a good impression on the Olympic committee," Mr. Spain said. "It gave us an idea that we were doing a little part in being able to sway the committee to pick Atlanta."The Atlanta Committee for the Olympic Games (ACOG) is hoping to get students excited about the Olympics "so they can be good hosts when our guests come in 1996," said Sandy Jernigan, co-coordinator of the Olympic Day in the School program, which is primarily geared toward middle schools.Four hundred of the 600 middle schools in Georgia now participate in the program, including all of Gwinnett's middle schools.A program for the state's elementary and high schools will be developed over the next few years, Ms. Jernigan said.Buford Elementary, however, already has the Olympic vision. Their program began April 17 and ran for a month. Throughout the last four weeks, the pupils have studied their countries and competed in athletic events in their physical education classes.Margaret Hanson, a physical education teacher, began holding an Olympics four years ago, but this was the first year the athletics competition was combined with the school's social studies fair.The project culminated last Friday with an international festival. With passports in hand, pupils traveled to different classrooms disguised as foreign countries.The pupils' transworld experiences included mummifying a doll in Egypt, making maracas in Mexico, eating chocolate and cheese in Switzerland and playing golf in Puerto Rico."People are all the same," first-grade teacher Gail Cary told a class of pupils dressed in authentic Saudi Arabian garb. Ms. Cary's country was Botswana. "It's your culture that's different where you grow up."

Email_Body: WILMINGTON, N.C. - This is his road, though the signs aren't up yet, the ones that will announce that this seven-mile stretch of salt air and interstate is Michael Jordan Road.Talk about open court. Nothing but a smattering of road signs dot Michael's bit of Interstate 40, assuring pilgrims to his hometown that the Azalea Optimists and Cascade Realty are taking care of litter. And that Barstow, Calif., is 2,554 miles due west. And how about that Michael Jordan exhibit at the New Hanover County Museum? Do you know, do you know, do you know?"Well that's misinformation that has caused us some problems recently," museum director Janet K. Seapker says.Let curator Barbara Rowe clear this up:"We have Michael's Olympic uniform and we borrowed his gold medal from his mother. And for a couple of years it was part of the Superstars of The Lower Cape Fear' exhibit. People loved it. We'll do it again."You mean Michael shared the exhibit with former Harlem Globetrotter Meadowlark Lemon, Sammy Davis Sr. and country singer Charlie Daniels?"And there's an actor in Atlanta from here, not very big, I think he's in the Senate or something," Ms. Rowe says. "Yeah, U.S. Rep.  Ben Jones. Cooter. We've got the jeans, cap and the sleeveless shirt he wore on The Dukes of Hazzard.' That's really neat. He came here and opened the exhibit."Oh, well. There are still some in this quiet, coastal community of 45,000 who say the Chicago Bulls superstar is their most favorite of sons.And if state and city fathers have yet to master the marketing acumen to make Michael Jordan as synonymous with Wilmington asNikehas done with him and their athletic shoes, one place remains as mythical as Michael Jordan's basketball talents - Laney High School.Namely, the scuffed hardwood in the crackerbox gymnasium, where a skinny teenager would practice alone at 7 a.m. before classes began. Then at night, he would dazzle the college scouts and basketball crazies, crammed to the rafters, with heretofore unseen acrobatics.Nearly every day, visitors ask to see the gymnasium. They glimpse Michael's gold and blue high school jersey in the glass case in the foyer - the familiar No. 23 emblazoned below BUCS, the team's nickname. They see his name engraved on a plaque honoring the Buccaneers' 1980-81 championship team.And if they're lucky enough to run into basketball coach Fred Lynch, they ask how was it Michael Jordan failed to make the varsity team as a 10th-grader. How, Coach, did arguably today's greatest player - a member of the University of North Carolina's 1982 NCAA championship team, a 1984 Olympic gold medal winner and the leader of a team seeking the 1991 NBA title - get cut?Mr. Lynch, then an assistant coach, has answered that question often. How there was only room for one 10th-grader on the varsity. How Leroy Smith, a 6-foot, 7-inch post player, was kept over a then 5-foot, 10-inch Michael Jordan. How Michael never showed his disappointment at playing junior varsity.By the time he was a 6-foot, 4-inch senior, he was All-Everything. Prep All-American in basketball. Top baseball pitcher. High jump champion. One of the nicest and most popular students ever at Laney."He showed that other people can make it if they try. That no one needs to act like they're special," says Jason Whitfield, graduating senior and basketball guard, who has heard this sports lore as gospel from his coach.So until the North Carolina Board of Transportation mounts the first sign near the Cape Fear River (possibly this summer at a ceremony attended by Michael), or until the memorabilia of Sammy Sr., Meadowlark and Cooter are retrieved from mothballs, the most authentic tribute to a native son remains a small gymnasium.
