Email_Body: The alleged rape at the Kennedy compound in Palm Beach, Fla., has caught the public's attention, and Time uses it as a hook in its June 3 edition to examine the issue of date rape.Writer Nancy Gibbs points out that deciding exactly what is rape is hard to determine in a society where some colleges define acquaintance rape as a spectrum "ranging from crimes legally defined as rape to verbal harassment and inappropriate innuendo."She notes that women call it a hidden crime, while some men blame it on women "who live to tease." The seven-page report includes interviews with women and also with men who feel unjustly accused. And a poll of 500 U.S. adults taken by Time and CNN shows the differences on the issue. Among the results: 54 percent of the women and 69 percent of the men say that some women like to be talked into having sex.WOMEN AND MEDICINE I: Another sort of abuse of women is examined in the June issue of Ms. In "Women as Wombs," Janice G. Raymond, professor of women's studies and medical ethics at the University of Massachusetts, questions the success of in vitro fertilization clinics. She says research has shown 90 percent to 95 percent of women who undergo IVF never take home babies. That finding is part of a wide-ranging report on the new reproductive technology.WOMEN AND MEDICINE II: In the June 3 issue of People, actor Gene Wilder talks about wife Gilda Radner's losing battle with ovarian cancer and how doctors could have caught it sooner.FACING UP TO PLASTIC SURGERY: Anyone considering a facelift or other plastic surgery may want to check out the June issue of Self. The piece, about top plastic surgeons, includes photos of a facelift in progress that are not for the squeamish.GUYS JUST WANNA HAVE FUN: The June issue of GQ takes a look at a male institution in "The Last Hurrah: Can the bachelor party survive feminism, premarital sex, AIDS and couch dancing? Should it?" Writer Stephen Fried pulls together anecdotes of parties ranging from the tame to the raunchy. He also includes a rating scale to help guys determine how much trouble various last flings might cause.SPIKE UP TO BAT: The cover photo on the May 27 issue of Sports Illustrated has some heavy hitters - Mickey Mantle and Roger Maris smiling broadly for a piece on the 1961 Yankees - but the real slugger isn't even promoted. Inside is a 10-page interview with filmmaker Spike Lee on topics ranging from being a superfan to hisNikecommercials to why he's such an angry young man. The search for what drives Mr. Lee goes back to his roots in Atlanta, Alabama and Brooklyn. Mr. Lee takes a jab at Deion Sanders, calling him "another young brother who got some money and will have it spent before he knows he had it." The article is cleverly illustrated with photos of Mr. Lee in various baseball uniforms, including the Atlanta Braves.AROUND THE SOUTH: The June issue of Atlanta magazine looks at the fall from grace of Emory University law school's Abe Ordover, who was accused of sexual misconduct. . . . The June issue of Southern Living offers a salute to national parks in the South as part of the National Park Service's 75th anniversary.AT THE CHECKOUT: "Joan Kennedy: How Ted's antics in rape scandal drove her into drink clinic, then back on bottle" - The Star . . . "Kennedy Rape Drives Joan Into Booze Clinic" - The National Enquirer . . . "Bob Hope Cheated on Wife & Drove Lover to Suicide" - The Globe.

Email_Body: Cover charges at Atlanta-area sports bars for the Mike Tyson-Razor Ruddock heavyweight fight June 28 are likely to cost about $ 30 and would soar to between $ 40 and $ 45 for an Evander Holyfield-Tyson championship bout.That's the prediction of Atlanta attorney Bobby Ronick, who represents local pay-per-view TV marketing company Worldwide Satellites Ltd.Covers at local sports bars for last month's Holyfield-George Foreman championship match ranged from $ 10 to $ 35, but the norm was $ 20. Most bars were at capacity, and that kind of demand will only push prices higher.The in-home pay-per-view fees for Holyfield-Foreman ranged from a norm of $ 35.95 to $ 70, and those prices also are expected to be higher for Tyson-Ruddock or a Tyson-Holyfield matchup.LOTTERY PLAN CUT: Faced with opposition from its senate's powerful majority leader, New York state has sacked a lottery proposal that would have been based on the NFL scores of Giants, Bills and Jets games.The lottery would have operated much like many office football pools. Participants would have selected one of 100 squares that are randomly assigned two numbers from one to 10. Those whose two numbers matched the final digits of the score would win.The NFL strongly opposes state lotteries linked to its games. The New York lottery was projected to raise $ 15 million a year.HORSES LOSING GROUND: Horse racing, once the nation's most popular form of gambling entertainment, trailed lotteries in dollars wagered, $ 21 billion to $ 11 billion, in 1990. . . . The NCAA has expanded its disability insurance plan to include baseball players in addition to football and basketball athletes. Players deemed likely to be taken in the first two rounds of the major league draft are eligible to purchase up to $ 900,000 in disability coverage.BYE-BYE, BO: With football/baseball star Bo Jackson sidelined at least temporarily with a hip injury, San Antonio Spurs center David Robinson may become a marketing superstar of similar magnitude. With a 25.6 points-per-game average with the Spurs and a mathematics degree from the Naval Academy, Robinson remains a lieutenant and civil engineer in the Navy Reserve and is an accomplished pianist - in short, the clean-cut role model corporations are finding more and more difficult to locate. Robinson already is in the fourth year of a $ 1 million endorsement contract withNike, and signed deals with Casio watches and Franklin Sports Industries while serving a two-year stint in the Navy after graduation. However, experts predict it is unlikely Robinson will reach Jackson's estimated $ 5 million-per-year endorsement income. . . . Claiming patent infringement, Avia is suingNikefor unspecified damages in U.S. District Court in Portland, Ore. The suit claimsNikeis using a cushioning system in its new Air 180 series - which sell for approximately $ 125 per pair - that is similar to Avia's "Cantilever" technology, protected by three patents dating to 1980.

Email_Body: The Action Awards Breakers have picked up where they left off last season. Hitting a robust .600, the Snellville-based men's softball team has qualified for one national, one divisional and three state tournaments.Last season's U.S. Slo-pitch Softball Association (USSSA) state Class C Team of the Year is 47-16 overall and is in the driver's seat to win the highly regarded Amateur Softball Association (ASA) state Bud Light Triple Crown series, which continues this weekend in Fort Valley, Ga. They won the first leg of the series three weeks ago. The series awards points based on a team's finish in three designated tournaments, with the points leader being declared the state champion. The champion also gets its room and board paid for in the national tournament later this summer in Steamboat Springs, Colo. The Breakers qualified for that tournament with the win three weeks ago."It's a pretty prestigious thing there in Colorado," coach Ric Jarvis said. "If we win the Triple Crown , we're probably talking a couple thousand dollars."The Breakers' success in the ASA series is just part of the team's fast start. They've already earned berths for this summer's ASA, USSSA and National Softball Association (NSA) state tournaments, as well as for the USSSA Southeast Divisional. They've finished second in two highly competitive tournaments - theNikeEarly Bird Tournament in Marietta and a USSSA divisional qualifier in Cartersville."We've been hitting the ball well, and our defense has been exceptional," said Jarvis, an original member of the team that was formed 10 years ago to play in a recreation league.The Breakers have done most of their damage by coming through the loser's bracket of recent tournaments. In the first Triple Crown event, for instance, they lost their opening game, then won the next nine to take the championship."We've had to come back a number of times. That says a lot about our team right there," Jarvis said. "We've played in more games that a lot of other teams because we've had to come through the loser's bracket so many times."The success is not new. Since becoming the Breakers in 1981, the team has gained statewide respect. Last year, four players - including Player of the Year Mike Jordan, Derrick Davis, Ron Ammnons and Roger Bailey - were named to the USSSA All-State team as the Breakers set a state record in Class C for points won in tournament play. By winning the state title, the Breakers moved up to play in USSSA's B classification this year."We're consistently one of the better teams in the state. People hate playing us," Jarvis said. "Through the years, we've really grown into a good team. It's been a longtime hobby for me."Other team members are Terry Gomez, Tim Fuller, Phil Taylor, Mark Williamson, Bo Davenport, Steve Harrison, Kevin Gaines, Tim Gaines, Sam Crowe, Greg Jones, Mike Lahey and Mark Azar.

Email_Body: Georgia basketball coach Hugh Durham and football coach Ray Goff never covered this much real estate on a recruiting trip.How about this for a golf fantasy? They played 72 holes on four different courses on the same day. In fact, they even stopped for lunch and accomplished it all in just over 11 hours."We could have played another 18," Durham said. "We still had two hours of light left, but we couldn't find another course." The golf-a-thon started at 8 a.m. Monday at Athens Country Club, which Durham and Goff played in one hour, 45 minutes, with each man riding his own cart. From there, after a 45-minute drive to Lake Oconee, they played the Harbor Club course in about two hours.After lunch at nearby Port Armor, which they played in two hours and 10 minutes, they drove a few miles down the road to Reynolds Plantation where, ironically, Georgia Tech's annual golf outing had just been completed. Playing their final course in just over two hours, Durham and Goff completed the 72 holes at 7:05 p.m.Neither player wished to reveal the final scores, lest somebody remember them when filling out foursomes for all those handicap tournaments to which they regularly are invited, but Durham was the apparent winner."We both played pretty good," said Goff, "but I don't think I saw Hugh miss two or three fairways all day. I wouldn't have wanted to play him for money."If you can believe it, though, Durham has spent busier days on a golf course. Last summer at singer Kenny Rogers's Beaver Dam Farms course, he played 100 holes in one day.JUST WONDERING: When was the last time in this town that there were more people talking about the Braves than there were people talking about the NBA Finals? . . . The NFL and the Atlanta Falcons will conduct a free clinic at 9 a.m. Friday at Morehouse College sponsored by Pro Set and Nike.Expected are 12 Falcons players, including safety Scott Case, linebacker Michael Reid and former return man Billy "White Shoes" Johnson.ON A MISSION: TNT sportscaster Ernie Johnson Jr. and wife Cheryl are in the process of adopting a Romanian child. Cheryl has been in Bucharest since May 16 with other hopeful parents from the Atlanta area and will bring home a 2 1/2-year-old boy who was abandoned at birth in a park and has lived in an orphanage with other undernourished children. "It's been quite an experience," said Ernie, whose children, Eric 6, and Maggie, 4, are eager to meet their brother. Aurel Mihia Johnson and his new mother will be home as soon as they obtain a visa. "We're going to call him Michael, which is what Mihia pretty much translates to," said Ernie, "but if he's got a real good fastball, we might stick with Aurel." . . . Part- time Channel 46 sportscaster Phil Van Horn was the producer of the ESPN special that ran Wednesday on Georgia quarterback Eric Zeier, the former Marietta High star. What the show didn't detail was the fact that the biggest challenge for the massively recruited Zeier, who graduated from high school early and enrolled in time for the Bulldogs' spring practices, was juggling appointments with the "escorts" he encountered at various schools within the recruiting period.REMEMBER, THE ICEBERG'S OUT OF BOUNDS: Talk about taking advantage of good lighting! They're holding the Cross Creek Arctic Open golf tournament in Iceland, just 31 miles south of the Arctic Circle, to take advantage of June 21, the shortest night of the year. There will be enough light available to play 36 holes at the Akureyri Golf Club. . . . The price of going to the ballpark is getting out of hand. According to a Team Marketing Report survey done for Major League Baseball, the average family of four will spend $ 76.22 while watching their team play a single baseball game. The figure covers the cost of four tickets, two beers, four hot dogs, four soft drinks, two baseball caps, two programs and parking. In some cities, don't forget the cost of paying a kid to watch your car so it's there when you return.(Seen or heard something for Sportscene? Call Sheeley at 526-5798.)

Email_Body: INGLEWOOD, Calif. - L.A., a city of 3.5 million, is either too sophisticated or too vain to ever admit being in a state of shock. Siege, maybe. Not shock.Shock is empty freeways. Clipper victories. Surfboard shortages. Thirty consecutive days of cloud cover and no rain. And no sun, either. But what happened inside the fabled Forum on Wednesday was, at the very least, an aftershock. The Chicago Bulls won the title . . . The Chicago Bulls won the title . . . The Chicago Bulls won the title . . . The Chicago Bulls won the title.Four games. Four victories. Three wins in the Forum, and just like that - it was that easy - Michael Jordan no longer is the lonely Bull. No longer the lonely superstar. Now, he has plenty of friends.Bird. Magic. Isiah. With this ring, he becomes wedded to Magic Johnson and Larry Bird, who formed an elite club back in the 1980s. Non- champions need not apply. Isiah Thomas finally broke down the door. Pounded on it twice, in fact. Now, Jordan.How good does it feel? Jordan cried. He was so overcome that he hid from NBC. "Where's Jordan, where's Jordan?" a frantic Bob Costas yelled, as he looked around the champagne-drenched locker room.Others came and went. The Rev. Jesse Jackson. Spike Lee. Ernie Banks. Johnny Kerr. Lakers GM Jerry West and assistant GM Mitch Kupchak. "Too crowded," West said, ending his search for Jordan.Still, no Michael. But somewhere, by now, he was surely smiling. He had guided the Bulls to their first-ever championship in 25 years. A party in Chicago awaits.L.A.? L.A. can mourn, can shake, can complain that it wasn't fair because James Worthy and Byron Scott were hurt and Magic Johnson too old and Elden Campbell too young, but it was eminently fair, and right, and America celebrates because the Good Guy doesn't always finish last.This time the Good Guy won. Jordan ate his Wheaties and did all the right things, and when the time came, he came through. Blocked shots, steals, jumpers, passes, breakaway dunks, scoop shots, Michael being Michael.For six years, he wondered if it was meant to be. Six long years. As a rookie, he was snubbed in the All-Star Game by some of the (Isiah) Thomas Gang for arriving in aNikesweatsuit. His second year, he broke his foot and feuded with GM Jerry Krause because - get this - Jordan regained his health and wanted to finish out the season.Krause said no.Jordan said yes.Guess who won that battle?Jordan would win others, as well, including a race for MVP honors with his good friend Johnson. But that was nothing. Nothing like this.Jordan and his teammates arrived at the Forum two hours before game time, eager to learn the condition of Worthy (ankle) and Scott (shoulder).Worthy arrived soon after in street clothes, and remained in street clothes. Scott changed into his jersey and went out to the court to test the shoulder.Some of the Laker faithful - and some non-partisans - suggested that L.A. had a better chance without Scott, who shot 27 percent in the first four games. Consider this exchange during the interview session on Monday at Inglewood High.Horde of media jackals: "How is your shoulder?"Scott: "Not good. I can't lift my arm. I can't shoot."Horde of media jackals: "Ha, ha, ha."Or, as Vlade Divac might say, "He make joke."But this was no joke. Scott slowly walked off the court. No go. No Worthy. No Scott. No chance? The Bulls hoped not. During the two days between games, they were determined to retain their edge.They resisted the lure of Hollywood, with Jordan even declining an invitation to appear on The Arsenio Hall Show, refused to become overconfident because of the injuries to Worthy and Scott, and the wounded ego of Magic, who dropped the Big One right here in the middle of the Forum on Tuesday. He might return for another season. He might not.Jordan empathized, but refused to become distracted.But would they win?They win. When it is finally, mercifully over, Jordan bolts for his coach, Phil Jackson, and engages Paxson, the hero, in the longest of embraces.As he enters the tunnel area, he is in tears. "I've never been this emotional in public before," he says, "but this is a great time to be emotional."

Email_Body: PORTLAND, Ore. - The Atlanta Falcons would still be in Suwanee tonight, not out west facing the Seattle Seahawks, if all of their expenses were not being picked up.The cost for the Falcons' roundtrip charter alone, approximately $ 70,000, would make the cross-country trip prohibitive under any other circumstances. Falcons expenses have been budgeted at $ 90,000. Still, Portland State, the scrimmage's sponsor, hopes to net about $ 100,000 from an anticipated sellout crowd of 23,000 at Portland Civic Stadium. Ticket prices range from $ 7.50 to $ 25.Nike,located in nearby Beaverton, Ore., is helping pay some of the expenses."For a school our size, the profit we make from the scrimmage will have a substantial impact on our program," said Portland State sports information director Larry Sellers. "This is a major-league event for us in every way you can think of."HOMECOMING: While many fans attending tonight's scrimmage will be coming to see former University of Oregon star Chris Miller, the quarterback most recognized in these parts may be Falcons assistant head coach/offense June Jones, who played at Portland State. A native of Portland who was instrumental in arranging the scrimmage, Jones passed for 3,518 yards and 25 touchdowns while operating the run-and-shoot offense as a senior at Portland State.Falcons safety Tracey Eaton, a native of Medford, Ore., also played at Portland State. Free agent fullback Pat Chaffey, a native of North Marion, Ore., played at Oregon State.BRIEFLY: The Falcons are close to a contract agreement with veteran defensive end Tim Green. . . . The three-year, $ 2.325 million contract signed Wednesday by first-round pick Mike Pritchard represents a 21 percent hike over that signed by last year's 13th overall pick, Kansas City Chiefs linebacker Percy Snow.. . . The Falcons resume camp workouts with a 3 p.m. practice Sunday.. . . Eight players did not make the trip to Portland because of injuries. Three who did are doubtful to participate.

Email_Body: Former North Carolina State basketball coach Jim Valvano will return to coaching for the first time since his ouster 15 months ago when he coaches theNikeAll-Star team for 10 days in Germany and France in September. Valvano, who worked as an analyst for ABC and ESPN after leaving N.C. State in the wake of violations by team members, said he was assured of at least one victory against the German national team. "I'll have NBA All-Stars Charles Barkley and David Robinson playing for me for that game," he said. But that will be their only appearance. The rest of the team will consist mainly of players who just finished college or with minor league pro experience.; Fly So Free wins Jim Dandy by 1 1/4 Fly So Free, beaten twice this year by Strike the Gold, held off a late charge by the Kentucky Derby champion to win the Grade II Jim Dandy Stakes at Saratoga on Sunday. Fly So Free, the 2-year-old champion, swept wide in the stretch to finish 1 1/4 lengths ahead of Upon My Soul. Three lengths further back was Strike the Gold, in his first start since losing the Belmont Stakes by a head to Hansel.; Ben Johnson not wanted for raceBen Johnson, once one of the biggest names in international track, is now being asked not to show up. Bengt Bendeus, organizer of an Aug. 5 meet in Malmo, Sweden, said that he canceled a contract worth a reported $ 160,000 for Johnson to race against Carl Lewis and world record holder Leroy Burrell. Johnson finished fourth in the 100 meters at the Canadian national championships Saturday in a disappointing time of 10.42 seconds.; Puerto Rico beats USBL stars 93-86Jose Ortiz, formerly of the Utah Jazz, scored 26 points to lead Puerto Rico to a 93-86 victory over a team of USBL all-stars in the championship game of the Winston World Basketball Cup in San Juan, Puerto Rico. It was the first time a team of U.S. professionals played in a tournament sanctioned by the International Amateur Basketball Federation. Wes Matthews and Lanard Copeland, who played for the Atlanta Eagles this season, scored 12 and six points, respectively.

Email_Body: Kendrick Register knows what he wants to wear back to school. Shorts. Jeans that have been intentionally ripped in the knees.NikeAir Jordans.Unfortunately for 8-year-old Kendrick, his mother has other ideas. Rita Register is buying her son "nice" pants - Dockers, Levi's 501 jeans, Duck Head khakis. Mrs. Register is still in that enviable position of having control over her son's wardrobe. She also follows the cardinal rule of shopping for back-to-school clothes:Take the child with you. If you don't, what you buy may hang in the closet all year.Another cardinal rule is:Set a budget, and make sure your children know how much you intend to spend."Last year, I spent close to $ 300 on his clothes, but that was for everything, including a winter coat," Mrs. Register said. "The sneakers run us about $ 80, though. It depends on what the Jacksons - Michael or Bo - or Michael Jordan wear. That's what he wants."Kendrick and his classmates at Powers Ferry Elementary School in Cobb County will be decked out in old favorite bluejeans and new, bright shirts and pants, according to Deborah Jacobs, the district manager for The Children's Place."Boys will be wearing activewear, fleece tops and bottoms, denim and color-block woven tops. Denim in a relaxed-fit' style is popular," she said."For girls, the No. 1 look is activewear, also," Ms. Jacobs said. "The big-over-small' look is big for girls, like mock turtlenecks over leggings or stirrup pants."No. 2 on the girls' list is denim, either blue or bright colors. Turtlenecks and sweaters with jeans are popular," she said.Tennis shoes are the footwear of choice for many youngsters, said Stride Rite's Amy Dodge. Some manufacturers have developed a washable leather sneaker, which is a favorite of the parents."Moms love sneakers they can wash," Ms. Dodge said.In dress shoes, durability and versatility are important. Saddle oxfords and camp mocs are popular sellers, Ms. Dodge said.Before spending money on a new wardrobe, parents need to keep in mind their school system's dress code.For example, tank tops are banned this year in the Marietta city schools, as are gang paraphernalia and pajama-like clothing. Students in Marietta will be sent home for baring their midriffs or for immodest dress.Cobb schools determine their own standards for dress, according to school system spokeswoman Barbara Robison. "There are some things that are systemwide, but again, those are enforced locally by each school."Principals in Atlanta schools make individual determinations as to what's app ropriate, according to a system spokeswoman.Parents were advised to check with their local school or school system for changes to existing dress codes.

Email_Body: A 16-year-old Jonesboro teenager is in stable condition at Southern Regional Medical Center today after being dropped off at his home beaten and unconscious Wednesday afternoon, according to hospital spokesperson Pam Whitten.Clayton police said Karlos Brown, 16, of 78 Darwin Drive, was taken to his parents' home in the locked trunk of an automobile at 4 p.m. He had been beaten about the face and the front half of his head had been shaved, according to Clayton Police Lieutenant Doug Jewett. He was also missing hisNiketennis shoes and a baseball cap, the lieutenant said.The teenager had apparently left home earlier in the day with the same four men who returned him to his home, Lieutenant Jewett said.Roderick Reid, 20, and Jerrmie Roberson, 18, both of Jonesboro, two of the men who allegedly brought the teenager home, were arrested and charged with aggravated assault and false imprisonment, Lieutenant Jewett said.Police have not established a motive and do not think the attack was gang-related, Lieutenant Jewett said.

Email_Body: ATHENS - Georgia scored a basketball recruiting coup Tuesday when Cedar Shoals forward Carlos Strong, whose strong showing this summer propelled him among the nation's top college prospects, said he would enroll next year."This kid is the next Dominique Wilkins ," said Bob Gibbons, a recruiting analyst. "I saw Dominique play in high school, and I think Carlos at this stage is better than Dominique was. I think by the time we get to the end of the year, Carlos could be the very best player in the country." Strong, a 6-foot-8 preseason All-American, also considered Kentucky, Tennessee and Miami after earlier eliminating Nevada-Las Vegas, Georgetown and Syracuse. Verbal commitments are non-binding. High school players cannot sign national letters of intent until Nov. 13.Strong, a first-team All-State Class AAAA player, averaged 15 points and eight rebounds last season. He was impressive at the prestigiousNike camp, a showcase of the country's top prep prospects, despite playing only two days after suffering a sprained ankle and broken tooth.Strong is the second of the nation's top five players to stay close to home. Guard Jason Kidd of Oakland stunned Kentucky and Kansas by committing to California last week."I feel like if you're good, people are going to know you're good whether you're on television a lot or not," Strong said. "The main thing is to go somewhere where you're comfortable and I'm comfortable at Georgia."Strong has met the NCAA's core curriculum standards but failed to achieve the minimum SAT score of 700 on his first try. He plans to retake the test later this month. Strong missed eight games last season because of academic problems.Georgia also remains in the running for Strong's Cedar Shoals teammate Terrell Bell. The 6-10 Bell has visited Alabama and Kentucky and will visit Temple, Clemson and Georgia.Former Griffin High All-American Darrin Hancock, now at Garden City (Kan.) Junior College, has narrowed his choices to Georgia, Kansas and Kentucky.

Email_Body: MEMPHIS - The word drops softly in a rich baritone, a towering double-breasted figure letting it go: Memphis. Willie Herenton tries to sell his mayoral candidacy with verse."We must build coalitions that cut across race and class. I grow weary. . . . We have an opportunity to send a message to the nation that Memphis," he says slowly, his opponent two feet away, "a city historically plagued by racial polarization, has made a sudden leap forward. Memphis . . ." The cadence evokes the late Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and is aimed beyond these 700 Rotarians, most of them white, gathered at The Peabody Hotel. It's aimed at the television cameras. The 6-foot-6 former Memphis school superintendent wants to be the first black mayor of this predominantly black city on the Mississippi.Voters will decide today whether he unseats popular incumbent Dick Hackett, who offers the flip side of the New South coin: economic development.Mr. Hackett, a 42-year-old business guru without a college degree, as a career politician has managed to transform Memphis into an attractive trading post. Eighty-five businesses, including such titans as Federal Express, International Paper andNike,have expanded or relocated here in the past year.Mr. Herenton, 51, grew up in a housing project 15 blocks from what is now a glimmering downtown. The same determination that made him a Golden Gloves boxing champion earned him a doctorate and made him the first black school superintendent.It was a post he held with distinction from 1978 until June. Only once was he tempted to leave. In 1987, the Atlanta school board offered him its top job. He accepted, only to withdraw weeks later, after an impassioned plea from the community to stay in Memphis.If ever there is a time for Memphis to elect a black mayor and join Atlanta, Birmingham and New Orleans, and five of the nation's top 10 cities, it is now. Timing, demographics and justice may be on its side.Census figures show that 55 percent of Memphis's 610,000 residents are black. And the U.S. Justice Department filed a voting rights suit against the city to abolish at-large council seats and run-off elections.Black leaders, who had never united behind a sole candidate for mayor despite only one black ever winning a citywide race, met during the summer to pick a consensus choice. That process ended up anything but unified when two coalitions warred over whose voice would be heeded: the traditional politicians led by U.S. Rep. Harold Ford or activists at a People's Convention.  Mr. Herenton emerged as the candidate of both, but not without casualties. Mr. Ford waited until the final week to lend his presence to the campaign and apparently chose not to issue a traditional endorsement ballot on Mr. Herenton's behalf.Charles Carpenter, Mr. Herenton's campaign manager, warns that no one should underestimate Mr. Herenton's appeal, which peaked after he decided to take the Atlanta job. "At that point it was clear to him, clear to the community, that Willie Herenton was a leader, a role model, and a mentor."The incumbent has adopted the look of a winner, attending official functions, dropping in on shopping centers and making speeches only at private fund raisers.Mayor Hackett says he is running on his nine-year City Hall record, one he claims is marked by sound management of services, no tax increases and a thriving economy.Rarely does he mention Mr. Herenton by name, nor are race relations given much comment. Instead he points to six black top city directors - most appointed in the past two years - as examples of his administration of inclusion.Campaign manager Bill Boyd says the mayor might get up to 15 percent of the black vote as a result of black dissension.He also has nearly three times the campaign funds of Mr. Herenton, or $ 660,000, enabling him to barrage viewers this week with television ads.

Email_Body: Authorities were trying Saturday to identify a jogger who was lying unconscious at Piedmont Hospital after being struck by a car on West Paces Ferry Road."He's very clean-cut looking," said hospital spokeswoman Linda Tucker. "His clothes seem pretty expensive."The victim is about 30 years old, white, 5-foot-8 and 170 pounds with a muscular build and dark brown wavy hair. He was wearing black running shorts,Niketennis shoes and a black sports watch. He has three tattoos - a leprechaun on his right chin, a dragon on his left shoulder and an eagle on his right arm. "He has a very serious head injury," Ms. Tucker said. "Right now it's very grave.  Doctors desperately need to talk to family to see if there are any other medical conditions they should be aware of."Witnesses said the jogger was in the path of traffic when he was hit on Friday. No charges were filed against the driver.PARENTS OF TEENAGE SHOOTING SUSPECT SUED: The parents of a 14-year- old who shot another youth during a basketball game are being sued for negligence because they allegedly left their son alone at home with access to a vehicle and a weapon. The $ 5.5 million lawsuit in Gwinnett State Court alleges that Edward and Denise Nestor "were aware of their son's dangerous propensities." Casey Brennan, 13, of Snellville was shot between the eyes on June 27. His parents, John and Pamela Brennan, say he has lost sight in one eye. Testimony indicated the Nestors' son, whose name is being withheld, drove his parents' van to a neighborhood basketball game and attempted to shoot Casey's brother, then shot Casey. A Gwinnett Juvenile Court judge ruled the youth committed aggravated battery. He faces a maximum sentence of 18 months in juvenile detention; sentencing is set for Oct. 15.CLARKSTON MAN HELD IN SLAYING OF FEMALE IMPERSONATOR: A 29-year-old Clarkston man has been charged in the Sept. 26 slaying of a female impersonator in Knoxville. Investigators charged Samuel U. McDowell with murder in the strangulation death of Frank W. Wilson, 46, who was choked with a telephone cord at his house. Mr. McDowell was taken into custody Wednesday in DeKalb County after he made an abrupt turn in front of officers, police said. He was driving a car that belonged to Mr. Wilson, investigators said. Mr. Wilson, who used the stage name "Francine," performed part time at a Knoxville nightclub. He also had worked for several years at a finance company. Mr. McDowell also was charged with theft of a vehicle. He is being held in the Knox County Intake Center in lieu of $ 22,000 bond.TWO HURT AS FIRE DESTROYS EAST POINT WAREHOUSE: An abandoned East Point cotton warehouse was destroyed Saturday morning in a blaze that sent two firefighters to the hospital with minor injuries. The fire in the two-story wood and brick warehouse at 1149 Central Ave. was reported at 12:46 a.m., and crews were still tending hotspots Saturday night, said East Point Fire Department Battalion Chief Ronnie Few. One firefighter was treated for smoke inhalation, and one slipped and fell on debris. Both were released from South Fulton Hospital. The cause of the fire had not been determined Saturday, but Chief Few said vagrants have been seen in the building.TWO INDICTED IN DALTON SLAYING, INCLUDING VICTIM'S WIFE: A Whitfield County grand jury has returned murder indictments against a Dalton man and the wife of the victim. Debra Thomas, 33, of Hartford, Ky., and formerly of Dalton, was indicted on murder charges in the strangulation of her husband, Roger Dale Thomas, 31, in May. The grand jury also indicted Jeffery Sean Roberts, 34, of Dalton on a murder charge. Tammy Rochelle Carpenter, 20, of Dalton was indicted for concealing Mr. Thomas's death. His body was found May 13 alongside Lake Allatoona by a fisherman. He had been strangled with a small rope. Mrs. Thomas filed a missing persons report May 11, telling police she last saw her husband when she dropped him off at a Dalton lounge. Detectives have said no one at the lounge recalled seeing Mr. Thomas.WATERING BAN LIFTED IN CHATSWORTH: Chatsworth residents now can water their lawns and wash their cars without guilt. The city water works lifted its monthlong ban on outside water use Friday after decreased industrial and residential demand boosted the supply. "If people still conserve and not be wasteful, I think we'll be OK," said water works superintendent Tom Martin.CONVICTED COLUMBUS MURDERER WON'T GET THE CHAIR: Jerry Lee Everett of Columbus has escaped the death penalty by pleading guilty to a 1988 murder and armed robbery. Everett, 36, pleaded guilty Friday to the Oct. 2, 1988, fatal shooting of Rudolph E. Williams behind the Traffic Light Lounge. Mr. Williams was shot in the head five times. Muscogee Superior Court Judge William Smith sentenced Everett to two life terms for murder and armed robbery and five years for using a firearm during those crimes. The sentences will run concurrently. Assistant District Attorney Ed Berry said Everett's videotaped confession as well as his action in calling police and telling them he committed the crimes led to the offer to escape a possible death sentence.MCINTOSH CLERK SUES COMMISSION OVER FIRING: A former McIntosh County tax commission clerk is suing county commissioners, claiming she was illegally fired after her arrest on forgery charges. Dotheria Robinson was arrested in February 1990 for cashing a check that was drawn by a third party and given to her husband. The charge was later dismissed on a technicality. Nine months after her arrest, the McIntosh commission voted to suspend Mrs. Robinson indefinitely. Her suit, filed in U.S. District Court in Brunswick, claims the commission usurped the authority of Mrs. Robinson's boss, the tax commissioner, and failed to follow county policy on firing employees. The suit says commissioners routinely ignore policy when firing black employees, like Mrs. Robinson. She is seeking unspecified back pay and damages, and reinstatement in her job.FEDS ASK GROVETOWN TO RETURN EPA FUNDS: Federal environmental officials are asking the city of Grovetown to return $ 169,000 for failing to award a 1986 sewer plant contract to the lowest bidder. Mayor Dennis Trudeau said the Environmental Protection Agency provided a $ 2 million grant for the city's wastewater plant, which was built after three separate contracts were awarded for segments of the work. W.L. Carey Construction Co. was the low bidder on the first two contracts, but Beacon Industries Inc. was the low bidder on the third contract by about $ 269,000, Mayor Trudeau said. City officials gave the entire project to the Carey firm after it agreed to drop $ 100,000 off the price of each of the three contracts. Although the $ 300,000 discount on all three contracts made Carey the low overall bidder, EPA decided that Beacon should have been awarded the third contract. EPA has ordered the city to repay the $ 168,000 difference between the low bid and the Carey price on the third contract. Email_Body: He is Wheaties. He isNike.He is America. He would be the prototypical Republican if he weren't a Democrat.Yet of late, Michael Jordan's halo is teetering, threatening to tilt, and all because of a Meet-the-President photo shoot last week in the Rose Garden. COME AS IS, the invitation urged. BRING CHICAGO BULLS. BRING TROPHY. MOST IMPORTANT, BRING MICHAEL. For a change, even George was there.And Michael wasn't.In the aftermath, Jordan's absence was added to the growing list of national crises. He was found guilty of a conspiracy of one, of (ye gads!) orchestrating a solo plot, a snub, against the Prez.Children cried. Mothers cringed. Both suggested that Jordan be flogged with a bowl of wet Wheaties, or, at the least, be grounded by a pair of P.F. Flyers.Others, including members of the Chicago media, deemed a verbal spanking more appropriate. Consider that Chicago columnist Jay Mariotti, echoing the very serious sentiments of many, called the snub, "about the most disturbing, irresponsible and irrational thing Jordan has done in public life."; Michael's virtues paling in comparisonJordan must indeed be a man of few sins. Unless we missed it, he does not use drugs. He pays his bills on time. He loves his children. In general, he comports himself like a gentleman, the same which can not always be said of his brethren.Larry Bird shoots his mouth off and often hits his own foot. Charles Barkley shoots his mouth off and hits both feet. Isiah Thomas, both feet and both ankles. Magic Johnson keeps mum. Much safer that way. Until recently, so did Jordan.First he hinted that he might prefer golf to the Olympics. Amid a sizable uproar, he quickly reconsidered. Then he was blamed - unfairly - for Thomas's absence on the U.S. squad. Now he is perceived as sticking out his very famous tongue at Bush.Hardly.Were he more of an activist, Jordan's absence might have suggested that Bush tend to the weeds in the back of his other garden, the one that provides a less-than-rosy vision of America, featuring its homeless, the health-care crisis, unemployed workers, our illiterate children.But Jordan's statement was personal and pragmatic, though impolitic as well. He simply chose to spend the final days of the offseason with his children, which, given the state of the American family, ought to be commended.; He owed fans answer, not justificationBush most assuredly will recover more quickly than our economy. So will the Bulls, even those angered by a perceived double standard, and so will Jordan, though the MVP has gained new insights into the plight of the superstar.The trouble with sports heroes is that they aren't angels. They may leap into the heavens but they eventually land, often with a thud. Even, the Michael Jordans.In one sense, his timing is lousy. Bird had Magic. Magic had Bird. They were basketball's dueling duo of the 80s, enemies, then rivals, and ultimately friends, each one's actions measured by the other's. Together, they shared the glories and the burdens of superstardom."I would always say, What would Larry do?' " Magic once admitted, deep in thought. " How would he react?' Having him out there . . . well, we helped each other's careers in a lot of different ways. We understand each other."But Jordan stands alone. He lacks the kinship of a Magic-Bird, and unlike his predecessors, veteran teammates with the stature of a McHale, Parish, DJ, Kareem, Wilkes, Worthy, Nixon. Jordan has only Jordan. Pippen? Not yet. Horace Grant? Just another good player. John Paxson? Right place at the right time.If Jordan is to be chided, it is only for this: He owed his fans the answer to his whereabouts. Not a justification. An answer.But irresponsible? Disturbing? Irrational? Nonsense. Jordan should simply tell the truth.Just explain that he's a Democrat.

Email_Body: Pauly Chu, a kindergarten teacher at Canby Lane Elementary School, structures her class in the normal fashion of most other kindergarten teachers.They read some, do math, learn Chinese, take naps and have play time - yes, they have been learning Chinese.Mrs. Chu, a Chinese-born American citizen, spends at least 30 minutes a day teaching the 5-year-olds numbers in Chinese, math on an abacus and Chinese characters. But she doesn't stop there. Some old Chinese culture is also incorporated into her classroom.Because, according to Mrs. Chu, the old way was the best way."A long time ago in China, the teacher was more important than the parents," Mrs. Chu said. "Discipline and respect was incorporated in the school; the most important thing was respect to the teacher. But when I came to the United States, I saw that that's not always the case."Bowing when thankful is natural for the 15 students who sometimes wear Chinese farmer hats made out of paper. Five-year-old Michael Witherspoon wishes everybody would do it."Learning Chinese makes me happy," Michael said. "I think everybody should bow and say thank you' because it's a really nice thing to do."Exposure is also important to Mrs. Chu. She believes understanding different cultures makes for better relations in the future."My students can see that I'm different from them, they know that that difference is that I'm Chinese," Mrs. Chu said. "Sharing some of my culture with them helps them understand that difference is a way of life, that it could be good and there is no reason to feel threatened."Brown-eyed Benjamin Carson credits Mrs. Chu with helping him make his career choice. The 5-year-old Stone Mountain resident said he wants to be a Chinese-speaking "rocketeer" when he grows up."They love her - both kids and parents," said Mary Dugett, the school's principal. "We have parents that come in wanting to see the teacher who teaches Chinese. After watching her, they inquire about getting their kid in her class.""I couldn't learn Chinese at my old school," 5-year-old Desiree Hillman said. "But Mrs. Chu is a Chinese teacher, and I like her because she teaches Chinese."Mrs. Chu said she's proud to have the opportunity to teach children another language."I really think Americans should learn more than one language," she said, "and I'm happy to be able to contribute towards that goal."According to Mrs. Chu, the old way was the best way.The SchoolCanby Lane Elementary KindergartenThe teacherMrs. Pauly ChuThe classNikeAmoleKimberly BrownBenjamin CarsonShaka DennisonStacie EdwardsJohn R. Email_Body: They are the unsavory types you would not want around your children. If these guys came to dinner, chances are you would count the silverware upon their departure.So why are some of the nasty boys of professional sports getting five-figure contracts to try and sell you on what deodorant you should put under your arms?Hulk Hogan, recently implicated as a customer in a steroid distribution case, endorses Right Guard deodorant. So does Charles Barkley, the Philadelphia 76ers forward who spit on a girl at courtside and threw water on another fan last season. The Right Guard triumvirate is rounded out by Brian Bosworth, a former Seattle Seahawks linebacker whose mouth turned out to be larger than his talent and who is best remembered for being suspended from the Orange Bowl while playing for the University of Oklahoma after a positive steroid test.So why would Gillette, the makers of Right Guard, spend money on these guys?"We are playing off their bad boy image," says a spokesperson for N.W. Ayer, the New York ad agency that designed the ads. "It's the way the campaign is supposed to work.""Brian's a bad boy, and I do think that sells," says Gary Wichard, Bosworth's agent.  So, in the topsy-turvy parlance of advertising, bad becomes good."To a certain degree, anybody is marketable," says David Falk, vice- chairman at Pro Serv Inc., a Washington, D.C. firm that represents a host of athletes, including the Atlanta Hawks' Dominique Wilkins. "But I've got to believe that the last five to 10 years there has been an increased awareness of behavior, off-court and on-court."To that end, most advertisers now include morals clauses in contracts with athletes. Overstep the moral bounds and you are out.But what are the bounds?"You have to look at it on an athlete-by-athlete basis," says Bob Dorfman, a copywriter with Foote, Cone and Belding advertising in San Francisco. "With something like the Right Guard campaign, the right idea can overcome a lot of bad personality aspects."Dorfman points to theNikeshoe commercial that ran after Barkley had his run-ins with the NBA and was heavily fined. In the commercial, David Robinson, the clean-imaged center for the San Antonio Spurs and anotherNikeendorser, asks Barkley, "Can you spell fine, Charles?"Still, there is a line."For example, I don't think you could get by with making fun of  Philadelphia Phillies outfielder Lenny Dykstra's drunken driving charge," Dorfman says.Athletics tie-ins with products is nothing new. Yankees catcher Yogi Berra said, "Me-hay for Yoo-Hoo. Fudge bars too-who" back in the 1950s. And the prize fights on Friday night television were the Gillette Friday Night Fights.Today that connection is stronger than ever. Products from soft drinks to motor oil to headache powder to automobiles to wrist watches are being pitched by everyone from fastballer Nolan Ryan to race driver Richard Petty to tennis player Gabriela Sabatini.And while Sabatini and Steffi Graf, both tennis players, rank among the top 10 athletes for outside endorsements internationally, it is largely a man's game in the United States."Tennis and golf both have international appeal," says Clive Chajet, chairman and chief executive officer of Lippincott and Margulies, an identity consulting firm. "But in the U.S. the hottest market right now are the men who play team sports, particularly players in the NBA."In the wider U.S. market, women athletes have a much more limited appeal as far as endorsements are concerned. Except for women who play tennis, nobody is all that interested in having a pair of shoes just because Monica Seles wears the same kind."So lucrative are commercial endorsements that some highly paid athletes make more from their endorsement contracts than from the salaries their teams pay them.Michael Jordan of the Chicago Bulls capped an NBA championship and a Most Valuable Player Award with a new endorsement contract. Gatorade is paying Jordan a reported $ 19 million over 10 years to try and get people to drink its product. Before setting that all-time high, Jordan'sNike contract went unrevealed but advertising executives suspect it was the single largest endorsement deal ever.All told, Jordan's endorsement income alone has been estimated at $ 10 to $ 15 million yearly. His salary is $ 2.1 million annually."Michael transcends everything," says Chajet. "His image has redefined marketing."  Arnold Palmer, a leader on the endorsement list long after he dropped from the top of golf tournament leader boards, has pulled in at least $ 5 million annually in endorsement contracts over the last decade.Jordan's image is of a squeaky clean, nice guy. And Palmer's image is of common man perfection."It is more than just athletic accomplishment that makes someone a sought-after endorser," says Nova Lanktree, executive director of Burns Sports Celebrity Service in Chicago. "There has got to be personality and a sense of acceptance of the person."Despite the limited success of Bosworth and Hogan, other athletes have not been able to exploit off-the-field endorsements because their image is suspect. Two examples mentioned by advertising executives are former heavyweight boxing champion Mike Tyson and Oakland A's slugger Jose Canseco.Canseco became the first baseball player to hit 40 home runs and steal 40 bases in a single season. But he also has had several run-ins with the law, including a charge of carrying a weapon while on probation for multiple traffic offenses. And after being a no-show at numerous public appearances, Canseco started his own call-in line so fans could hear his side of the story.Tyson, who is scheduled to be tried for rape on Jan. 20, seems to cause even more consternation, though it took a rib injury to postpone his Nov. 8 championship fight with heavyweight champion Evander Holyfield."Tyson is the most unpredictable athlete out there," Dorfman says. "He's scary . . . You have to have some pleasantness about you."A lack of "pleasantness" has hit Tyson in the pocketbook. In 1988 Pepsi agreed to pay him about $ 1 million to push its products, but the contract was not renewed in the wake of allegations by Tyson's former wife, Robin Givens, that he physically abused her."There are only so many dollars out there for the credible athletes," says Atlanta attorney Bruce Church, who represents former Brave Dale Murphy. "The involvement costs are too high to gamble with. The cost not only of getting the athlete involved but getting the message out in front of the public.""It inherently holds that when you hitch your product image to a star, there is some degree of risk," Chajet says.To most, the line is distinct: Law-breakers are taboo."On a very literal basis, when it starts to get into the area of legality and criminality, then it starts to backfire," says Lanktree. "Barkley is a kind of naughty boy but he is not seen as a bad person. And I think that in view of Hulk's previous clean reputation, he's going to be all right."Lanktree contrasts Hogan's alleged use of steroids with that of sprinter Ben Johnson, who was stripped of his world and Olympic records after testing positive.Though Johnson did not have a many lucrative endorsement contracts, the setting of the world sprint record could have opened up international possibilities for him, Lanktree says."Ben Johnson took prescription drugs," she says. "What he did was not illegal, but he totally lost all his value as a spokesperson ."He was seen in the beginning as someone who was difficult, unapproachable. He was never likeable and his lapse into illegality cinched it."Baseball's all-star balloting, where the fans elect the starters, is a barometer of an athlete's standing in his community, Lanktree says.She notes that in 1990 Wade Boggs was voted by fans to start the All- Star Game despite a well-publicized extramarital affair."Whatever Boggs's attitudes was, he was not seen by the people of Boston as s aying, Screw you. I don't care what you think,' " she says. "On the other hand, Canseco was not elected to the All-Star team. I think that was very significant."Everyone agrees the future will see more athletes endorsing products."The Jordan deal was monstrous," says Dorfman. "How much Gatorade will people have to drink for that much money to pay for itself? But I think what it says is that advertisers think the market is bottomless.""More and more," says Lanktree. "I don't know that there is a limit."

Email_Body: Those TV commercials that Dave Thomas, founder of the Wendy's hamburger chain, has made famous are not to be confused with, say, a Bo Jackson production fromNike.But you still remember them, don't you?"Dave's commercials are a lot like sausages," joke creators Paul Basile and Jim McKennan. "If you like them, you probably don't want to see them being made." Thomas will sign copies of his book, "Dave's Way," from 1 to 2:30 p.m. today at Oxford Book Store on Pharr Road. An adopted child, Thomas is President George Bush's national spokesperson on adoption.Aspiring millionaires might heed "Dave's Plan for Making It if You're Young, Alone or on Your Own":1. Get a job.2. Don't be discouraged if an early job doesn't work out.3. Look for things you like and learn what it takes to have them.4. Try hard work.5. Find people you can learn from.6. Get an education.7. Figure out what the bottom is.Sounds like a few rules Bobby Cox followed in spring training.HAVE I FORGOTTEN ANYTHING?: There was lawyer John Johnson at the World Series the other night, having a great time and entertaining clients, when he was paged in the third inning and told by wife Chris that their son Drew, 4, could not be found. She wanted Johnson to check for him in, of all places, his car, remembering that Drew had pleaded to go with his dad to the game.When Johnson got to the parking lot, he saw several police officers encircling the car. They were talking to Drew, who had climbed into the back seat, fallen asleep and was now awake. Johnson took him home and returned to the game, missing two innings. "I'm not sure he's learned his lesson," Johnson said. "He thought he was a celebrity."KNOWING THE AUDIENCE: Pity the person scheduling an event these past couple of weeks without taking Braves fever into account. Cartier sent mailgrams Fri day informing those planning to attend the gala opening of its Lenox Square store Sunday that TV monitors would be placed "so that no fan will have to worry about missing the game." . . . Santa Claus, scheduled to arrive at CNN Center today to initiate the local Toys for Tots drive, switched the trip to Nov. 18.GOOD OBSERVATION: Members of a second-grade class at Fifth Avenue Elementary School in Decatur wondered why the World Series is being called "the Cinderella Series." The teacher read "Cinderella," then asked if they noticed any similarities between the story and the World Series. "Yes," said student Jamarco Williams. "They both get over at midnight."Items? 526-5800; faxes 526-5509.

Email_Body: Sometimes Father knows best. But other times you've got to make your own choices.That's a lesson Greg Asman learned in last year's AT&T Collegiate Investment Challenge when he bought stock in his father's company, Schlumberger Industries - and lost money. "That's the last time I'm going to do that," said Greg, a junior at North Springs High School in Atlanta.Luckily, he had stuffed his portfolio with other stocks, including NCR Corp.,NikeInc. and Walt Disney Co., so he still managed an imaginary four-month profit of about $ 200,000 on his $ 500,000 investment.This year, about 12 students from North Springs's 70-member chapter of Future Business Leaders of America are playing in the contest's high school division. Each has paid $ 39.95 for a contest kit.Between now and Feb. 28, their goal is to turn a fictional half- million-dollar investment into a money-making machine. They're competing against about 12,000 high school students nationwide.Rules of the tradeParticipants trade stocks by calling an 800 number during regular stock market hours. They can buy stocks on margin by borrowing from the "broker," Wall Street Portfolios, or sell stocks short. A commission is charged for each transaction. Each player is allowed 50 transactions.The 10 students who can make their portfolios grow the most win the contest.After making six-figure stock deals, the $ 1,000 prize may seem like chump change. It's a good thing they're not all in it for the money.Joe Reynolds, a junior who is a novice in the world of high finance, is looking at the contest as a learning experience and expects "hard study" ahead.That's encouraging to the business club's advisers, teachers Mary Henson and Cindy Greene. Ms. Henson says the contest is a "great opportunity for kids - lots better than anything we can simulate in class."Stock preferencesSeveral students are using research from class to choose investments.Sophomore Jay Carroll is considering investing in Pepsico, a company he researched for an economics class. He's also thinking about baseball card makers.Greg is considering "stocks based in the South, just because I don't think the recession has hit as hard here." He also likes airline stocks, Disney and Microsoft Corp.Despite Greg's experience last year, several students are investing in a parent's company.Marc Seidband's father works for IBM Corp. "I'm putting my money in IBM and Hershey," said Marc, a senior.His investment strategy: "Buy low, sell high. That's all you need to know."Learning from prosWhile that may be the key to winning AT&T's four-month-long contest, actual investors must look at things a little differently.Phillip M. Larkins, director of investments for Bank South Corp., suggests remaining in the market at least three years, because in the short term, "you can be blindsided.""The market is volatile, subject to major moves up and down," he said. So if you stay in stocks for a short period, "you're speculating, rather than investing."Karl Dasher, a Georgia Tech student who was the top-placing national sophomore in last year's college division, agrees that real investors must have a long-term perspective.Explaining why, he invoked the name of the legendary former manager of Fidelity Investments' high-flying Magellan Fund."You can't have one good three-month stint in the contest," Mr. Dasher said, "and think you'll be the next Peter Lynch."

Email_Body: Donald DeGreve, 65, playing golf recently with about 40 neighbors in Winter Haven, Fla., suffered a heart attack and died during his round. The body remained on the 16th green with a sheet over it more than two hours and, while his three partners abandoned their game, the rest of the group played around the green. "Life goes on," said one, "so we had to keep going."  ROMANTIC DEVIL: Romance is alive and well and running long distances. Joyce Hodges of Millen and Jim Hite of Statesboro will spend their honeymoon running the Atlanta Marathon and half-marathon on Thanksgiving. Both are ranked statewide in age-group (50-59) racing. Hodges coaches and teaches at Metter High while Hite does the same at Statesboro High.BLACK SUNDAY: Alma Alta, the Soviet basketball team in town to play Georgia State today in an exhibition, asked to meet "the football coach in black," no doubt reminded of their own KGB. So the 17 Soviets watched the Falcons practice Friday and the man in black, Jerry Glanville, came up with 17 tickets for Sunday's game against Tampa Bay. HERE & THERE: Michael Jordan drew a $ 250 fine from coach Phil Jackson for sleeping through a practice. George Shirk of the San Francisco Chronicle computed the fine was equivalent to a $ 50,000-a-year person losing 60 cents. . . . The Bulls' Scottie Pippen has his name on a newNikeshoe that'll hit stores next month. The shoes will be called Air Flight Mid. . . . New Notre Dame coach John MacLeod has renamed the Irish basketball arena The Thunderdome. That's the nickname the school is using for a marketing campaign. MacLeod wants to enliven games with all the hoopla that surrounds NBA contests. . . . Louisville coach Denny Crum has a 75-acre horse ranch in Kentucky. Says Crum: "When I get out of coaching, I plan to train thoroughbreds I've raised on my own." Might be less stressful for him. Whoever heard of graduation rates for horses?RIM SHOT: After Orlando rookie center Stanley Roberts shattered two backboards in practice, team GM Pat Williams came up with a way to raise money for charity. The club collected the shards, put them into bags and is selling them to fans for $ 10 a bag. At the first game - labeled as "Roberts' Rim Wreckage" - 34 were sold.QUOTABLE: After a 7-0 loss to Minnesota, Maple Leafs coach Tom Watt said: "It's pretty tough to find anything positive in this one. We didn't tear the jerseys - I guess that's it." . . . FSU's Bobby Bowden says today's showdown vs. Miami will not be the biggest game he has ever coached: "I have a lifetime contract. The biggest games I ever coached were when I had a one-year contract." . . . Oiler defensive end Sean Jones, on the Cowboys: "The Cowboys are like a bunch of little maggots. Right when you get them off you, they keep coming back."RIP RIPS DUKE: Former Georgia Tech assistant and current James Madison football coach Rip Scherer said he will withdraw his name from consideration for the Tulane job if David Duke wins Louisiana's gubernatorial election today. "It's a matter of principle. You'd be endorsing Duke's philosophy. I wouldn't want my name associated with anything of that kind."HAPPENINGS: Quarterback Chris Miller and 15 Atlanta Falcons teammates will sign autographs for charity today from 1 to 3 p.m. at Baselines Sports Cards in Duluth. Autographs of all players can be received for a $ 10 donation, which goes to the Christian Council of Metro Atlanta Shelter for Women and Children.WHO?: What a quarterback matchup - Steve Bono vs. Stan Gelbaugh. That's the 49ers vs. the Cardinals in case you don't recognize the names. How obscure are they? The 49ers couldn't find a scouting report on Gelbaugh. No wonder. He's been signed and released 20 times by eight teams in three leagues since 1986.A GREAT GUY: Tampa Bay linebacker Broderick Thomas was named NFC defensive player of the week after 11 tackles and two sacks against the Lions. He immediately announced his desire to renegotiate the remaining two years of his five-year, $ 4.3 million contract.NEW WORD: Before fighting Ray Mercer, heavyweight Tommy Morrison said: "Losing is not in my vocabulary." During the fight, says the Boston Globe's Ron Borges "Mercer made unconsciousness part of Morrison's vocabulary."Items? Arey at 526-5798; faxes 526-5977

Email_Body: Investors pushed stock prices sharply higher for much of the day Monday, although a late sell-off deflated most of the gains.The Dow Jones average of 30 blue chip industrial stocks, up as much as 19 points just 15 minutes before the market's regular close, ended the day with a gain of 4.69 points to 2,919.05 in fairly heavy trading. That was enough to keep alive the market's advance, which began last week. On Monday, the prospect of another interest rate cut by the Federal Reserve was enough to stimulate buying.The Fed's policy-making Open Market Committee is expected to decide the issue when it meets in Washington today, although analysts said there is no guarantee a cut in rates would occur the same day.Although the market is still cautious in light of the weak economy, some analysts interpreted the Dow's latest gains as further evidence that the worst of the market's monthlong slide may be over.Robert S. Robbins, market strategist for Robinson-Humphrey, said the Dow's low of 2,844 last Wednesday may have been the start of the market's usual year-end rally.In Monday's trading, two companies with improved earnings posted gains:Nike,up $ 2.62 1/2 to $ 64.50 after reporting second-quarter earnings of 80 cents a share against 77 cents a year ago, and Circuit City, up 12 1/2 cents to $ 23.25 after reporting earnings of 19 cents a share versus 5 cents a year earlier.

Email_Body: 'THEY kill for Reebok pumps. You only get mugged forNike-Air - they're commoner.' So I was informed by my 11-year-old son, who had just returned from the first day at his new secondary school wearing the gleaming pair ofNike-Airs which had gobbled up most of the household fund the day before.It was a remark going straight to the heart of a moral dilemma which, if the conversations I took part in during the last weeks of the holidays are anything to go by, has caught parents of children in our style-conscious society, where status currently resides in footwear, by the short and curlies. Should we succumb and fork out inordinate sums of money for shoes which, to the uninitiated, look much like those available at a fraction of the price, just because they carry the crucial name and have the attraction of added air? If common sense were the only guide, the answer should be a resounding no. But we are a child-centred generation of parents and we know only too well the depth of the anguish our young may feel if they cannot hold their own among their peer group. I still remember how mortified I felt when my mother adapted an ancient, baggy pair of her ski trousers for me, when everyone else on the school trip had the sleek, chic elasticated kind. For our kids, starting at new schools, there seemed to be a particular urgency to reach a decision.But there was a practical side to the dilemma. In the US there have been cases of youngsters murdered for their expensive, ultra-fashionable shoes, and not long ago the son of a friend of mine was 'persuaded' by a couple of heavies at a north London bowling alley to accompany them to a quiet spot and part company with his new, modish trainers. What sort of parent is willingly going to put their kid to that kind of risk when a pair of cheapo, label-less shoes are risk-free?Statistically, my son pointed out, this argument is thin - no more than half a dozen cases of nasty incidents concerning shoes have been reported and in our circle just two are known about. And, he asked in his most persuasive, hectoring manner, how many pairs of fashionable shoes are bought and worn by young people?But let's get to the heart of the moral dilemma. How can we right-on parents, desperately trying to impart values which will challenge the superficial materialism of our age - a culture in which the adman rules and you are admired more for how you look than who you are - go out and buy our kids these absurdly over-priced shoes, thus confirming the idea that this is where their status lies?The British Telecom lines crackled with the anguished sound of the older generation battling with its conscience as the start of the new term drew near.My conclusion was that there are times, the first day at a new school being one of them, when my principles, my pious pride in being seen to provide the right ethical environment for my young, have to go hang. Watching Cato putting on his new purple and white shoes with enormous pride, seeing the boost they gave to his confidence as he set off to school, I was glad he had them. It might not be the most satisfactory or the most enduring way to build self-esteem but as a one-off it had real value.He arrived home after the first couple of days happy with the school, pleased to be making new friends, excited even about his homework. I can't help feeling that if he had not felt so sure about his image, he might not have felt so positive about all these other things.I was not, apparently, alone in my judgment. Walking into the entrance hall of my son's new school that first day, the most striking sight was a dazzling array of feet in state-of-the-art footwear.

Email_Body: Leo Wilson Jr., 16, was shot to death for hisNikesneakers and satin sports jacket, police say.  Police were questioning three people ages 18 to 22 in Wilson's murder, said Lt. Steven Jacobsmeyer of the homicide division.  A charge of first-degree murder against one of the three was taken under advisement Friday by the St. Louis circuit attorney's office.  Police were continuing to investigate, Jacobsmeyer said.  Wilson was shot moments after leaving his girlfriend's house shortly before midnight Monday in the 6000 block of Etzel Avenue, in the Cabanne neighborhood, police said. He was robbed of his black-and-whiteNikeshoes and a satin black-and-silver jacket bearing the logo of the Los Angeles Raiders, said homicide Detective Joe Nickerson.  Wilson lived nearby, in the 5800 block of Page Boulevard.  He was shot once in the abdomen and twice in the leg. He was found on a driveway on Etzel and died at 6:50 a.m. Tuesday at Barnes Hospital.  A neighbor of Wilson's girlfriend told police that she had heard what sounded like Wilson say, ''Are you all going to kill me?'' That was followed by several gunshots, the witness told police, Nickerson said.  Police say the three being questioned accosted Wilson. They were part of a group of five who had committed five other robberies between 11:30 p.m. and midnight Monday. In each case, the youths took satin pro team jackets, satin caps or tennis shoes from their victims. Nickerson said the three youths claimed to be part of the ''Crips'' gang.  But Lt. Thomas Malecek of the police department's juvenile division said the youths were probably gang ''wannabes.'' Teen-agers in cities along the coasts have been killed for their sports jackets or sneakers, and robberies of those items are on the increase in St.  Louis, said Malecek. Teen-agers here have been shot for their jackets or shoes, but Malecek said this was the first case he knew of in which a youth had been killed.  ''It's becoming a growing problem, because apparently these items have a lot more identity value than in the past,'' Malecek said.  Wilson's mother, Reata Wilson, said Friday that she could not believe her only son had been killed for a pair of sneakers and a jacket.  ''If they wanted it, they could have took it and let my child live,'' she said. ''He was a good child, very playful, and always kept us laughing.  We're going to miss him.'' Leo Wilson was a sophomore at Southwest High School and enjoyed weight-lifting, his mother said. Among the other survivors are two sisters: Michelle Wilson, 19, and Cher Wilson, 15.  Reata Wilson said her son had wanted to start his own carpentry business when he graduated from high school. She said he liked to work with wood.  ''We've got a lot of pieces here at the house that he made himself,'' she said.  ''I want the police to find out who did this, so that person can be punished,'' she said.  Bill Bryan of the Post-Dispatch staff contributed information for this story.

Email_Body: SHOOTING A BULLET with a bullet is, in effect, what the Army's Patriot missiledoes when it kills an incoming Scud.  So far, the Patriot appears to be knocking down each Scud that has come under fire. This success stems from a mixture of high technology and luck.  Finding a defense against ballistic missiles - missiles whose flight path forms a high, inverted ''U'' at thousands of miles a hour - has become for military researchers the hunt for the Holy Grail.  For more than 40 years, the United States has invested tens of billions of dollars in trying to develop an anti-missile missile. TheNike-Zeus program of the '50s gave way to the Spartan and Sprint programs of the '60s.  The search slowed slightly after 1972, when the United States and the Soviets signed an Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty limiting each to only one anti-missile launching area.  Still, anti-missile research continued through the '70s. It exploded in the '80s under President Ronald Reagan, who launched the Strategic Defense Initiative - instantly dubbed ''Star Wars.'' Although the Patriot incorporates some of the Star Wars technology, the program itself dates back almost 30 years and is rooted in the Sam-D anti-aircraft missile of the early '60s.  At that time, the Army wanted: A replacement for itsNikeHercules (a high-altitude anti-aircraft missile) and its Hawk, at least as its medium-altitude role.  A more self-contained missile unit, or battery, that would allow soldiers to move it more quickly around the battlefield. The most accurate missile in the world - a specification that caused big problems.  This cutting-edge-of-technology approach nearly killed the Patriot in Congress because it added billions of dollars in cost and forced a 15-year development program.  But in the end, the extra money and time let the Patriot blast Scuds from the sky.  Each Patriot battery has a radar set, a command center, an electric power plant and eight boxy ''launching stations,'' which look like large freight containers, each with four missiles. All the equipment rides on vehicles or trailers.  The core of the system is called ''phased-array'' radar - the latest radar, in which the antenna stands still while the electronic signals move in high-speed bursts.  The radar first detects the incoming Scuds, then ''tracks'' them - plots their course - and finally guides the Patriots to the Scuds. The radar performs the tasks of nine types of radar of the oldNikeHercules and Hawk missile batteries.  The solid-fuel Patriot is 17.5 feet long and 16 inches in diameter. In theory, even a near-miss with its 200-pound fragmentation warhead will kill a Scud. But for all practical purposes, the speeds involved demand a direct hit.  The Scud is coming in at several thousand miles a hour, and the Patriot is going out at more than three times the speed of sound - about 2,200 mph at sea level.  That makes timing critical, said retired Army Lt. Gen. Daniel Graham of High Frontier, a private group that pushes Star Wars.  ''You've got only a couple of minutes,'' Graham said, to detect and track the Scuds and fire the Patriots. Even with their range of more than 40 miles, the Patriots destroy the Scuds only 2 to 4 seconds before the Scuds would otherwise hit.  At this point, the element of luck is critical.  Graham said the Patriot crews were improving the odds by double-teaming each Scud with two Patriot missiles.  But continued success for the Patriot depends on two critical factors: Whether the Scuds will be fired at targets within the Patriot's protective umbrella.  Whether the Scuds will be fired in limited barrages.  The Patriot has a limited ''footprint'' - the area it can defend.  ''The exact footprint is classified, so I'm not going to give you that,'' Graham said. ''But I can say the Patriot is designed to defend something the size of an airfield rather than an entire city.'' And just as the Patriot's area is limited, so is its ability to cope with mass waves of missiles.  Although the radar is said to be able to track 100 targets at a time, Graham warned that the number that can be actually shot at is limited.  ''Each battery has eight launchers with four missiles each, so that's 16 targets,'' Graham said, assuming two Patriots for each Scud.  Before the war, the Army had four Patriot batteries in Saudi Arabia. Graham said he had not heard of any more being sent. But he says that given the experience of recent days, more might be.  Few people say the Patriot fulfills the promise of Star Wars. An Iraqi Scud is a far easier target than a Soviet intercontinental missile with maneuverable warheads.  But as long as Iraq keeps hitting warfare's equivalent of high pop flies, Patriot crews should continue to catch the Scuds.
